Stock futures continued to slip lower ahead of Wednesday's open as earnings reports weighed to the downside.
Dow futures dropped 20 points. Nasdaq 100 futures traded down 5.3 points and S&P 500 futures were off 2.8 points.

Action in overseas markets was mild as uncertainty over the staying power of the Greek debt deal and bailout accord dragged on trade. Asia's markets closed slightly higher. Europe's markets traded fractionally lower after a purchasing manager's index showed the euro zone's service sector slipping from mild expansion to mild contraction in February.

Gold dipped slightly to below $1,755 an ounce. Oil prices were off a few cents, holding just below $106 a barrel. Oil closed at $105.84 Tuesday, up 9% since Feb. 2 and at its highest close in nine months. Uncertainty over oil supplies out of Iran appear to have driven the gains.

In stocks, global positioning system device maker Garmin (GRMN) shot up 12% in premarket action. The company pounded analyst expectations, citing a rise in personal navigation system device sales for the first time in several quarters. Q4 EPS were 96 cents, up 16%. Analysts had expected 65 cents. A 9% gain in revenue to $910 million also easily beat views. The company lifted both earnings and revenue guidance above forecasts.

High-end home builder Toll Brothers (TOL) pared losses and was down 3% ahead of the open. Weak first quarter home deliveries dragged Q4 results to a loss of two cents per share vs. views for a two-cent gain. Revenue slipped 4% to $322 million, below forecasts for $360.8 million. Home deliveries slipped 1% year-over-year, and the company's customer cancellation rate increased to 6.2%, vs. 5.7% a year ago.

Chief Executive Douglas Yearley, Jr. said typically, the first quarter is the most challenging time to gauge home buyer sentiment, but, in general, "the market feels healthier than it did one year ago."

Dell (DELL) dropped 7% in premarket trade after reporting late Tuesday its Q4 earnings fell 4% to 51 cents - a penny below views. A 2% gain in revenue to $16.03 billion cleared forecasts, but the company's Q1 revenue guidance didn't. Citigroup and Needham downgraded the stock to neutral and hold, from buy.

The session is in some ways overshadowed by a busy schedule of after-hours earnings reports. SAN FRANCISCO — Apple (AAPL) on Monday announced a refreshed lineup of MacBook computers, enhancements to its Siri personal assistant, Facebook integration, and Apple map software that will replace an offering from rival Google.
The announcements at Apple's Worldwide Developers Conference in San Francisco included no big surprises, such as those related to the rumored iPhone 5 and Apple iTV, and Apple shares fell 1.6%.
The annual event, however, is targeted to software developers who make apps for its Macintosh computers, iPhones and iPads, rather than to consumers.
Apple's new notebook computers include the latest Intel (INTC) chips and Nvidia (NVDA) graphics processors. The redesigned MacBook Pro computers mirror the super-thin design of the MacBook Air.
Apple's 15-inch MacBook Pro features a super-high-resolution Retina display, such as those found on the new iPhones and iPad.
With Apple's new MacBook Pro notebooks, the company is betting that it can get people interested in buying expensive laptops again.

"They were able to inject an awful lot of excitement into a price tier that has almost completely gone away," said Ezra Gottheil, an analyst with Technology Business Research. "All of a sudden they've caused a lot of people to think, 'Maybe I can justify spending $2,200 on a notebook PC.'"

The MacBook Pro starts at $2,199 and has standard configurations costing as much as $2,799. The new MacBook Pro computers pack a lot of advanced technology, including the latest processors, long battery life, thin chassis and high-resolution screen, he says.
The new notebook lineup should increase Apple's average selling prices and the company's PC profit margins, Gottheil said.

Apple executives took shots at rival PC makers who are attempting to compete with Apple notebooks with so-called ultrabooks running Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows operating system. Expect to see more ads for ultrabooks when Microsoft releases its Windows 8 operating system this fall.
Chides Copycats
"Everyone is trying to copy (the MacBook Air)," said Phil Schiller, Apple's senior vice president of worldwide marketing. "But they find it's not so easy."
Apple said its latest Mac operating system, Mountain Lion, will be available in July.

And Apple previewed its latest mobile device operating system, iOS 6, which will be available in the fall. It includes 600 new features, such as a new Maps app with Apple-designed cartography, turn-by-turn navigation and Flyover view. This feature might have sparked the biggest ovation from the developers, who sold out the presentation in 90 minutes.
The company's Siri voice-command software will support more languages and provide access to sports scores, restaurant recommendations and movie listings.

Several carmakers, including BMW and Jaguar, have committed to adding a Siri button to their steering wheels within the next 12 months, said Scott Forstall, Apple's senior vice president of iOS software.

"We want to integrate Siri even better with a car, so we're working with a number of car manufacturers to enable you to use a button right on the steering wheel to talk to Siri," Forstall said. "Since Siri can talk back to you and you don't need to light up the screen of the iPhone, you keep your eyes on the road and your hands on the wheel."
Siri now is available in Spanish, French, Italian, German, Korean, Mandarin, Cantonese and other languages.
Apple also is integrating Facebook (FB) support into its contacts, calendar and photo apps, among others.
Direct Facebook Login

With iOS 6, people will be able to log directly into Facebook through the main settings. That way you won't have to log in every time you open a new app. This potentially will allow Facebook access to a slew of new user data.
Apple CEO Tim Cook said 30 billion apps have been downloaded from Apple's App Store.
"This is a number that is so mind-boggling and was unthinkable just a little while ago," he said.
He knocked tablets running Google's (GOOG) Android operating system for their lack of software applications.
Apple's App Store has 650,000 apps, with 225,000 optimized for the iPad. Android has only "several hundred" tablet apps, he said.
Apple also is taking on Google Wallet with Passbook, an app that collects boarding passes, gift cards and other digital currency from apps into one place.
The app will send you an alert on your phone when you get close to a Starbucks (SBUX), if you have money on your Starbucks digital gift card.

Apple also announced that iPhone and iPad users will be able to use the FaceTime video chat application over cellular networks for the first time. Previously, FaceTime was limited to users on Wi-Fi networks.
Besides Apple, other stocks impacted by Apple's announcements on Monday included GPS navigation device maker Garmin (GRMN), Google and graphics chipmaker Nvidia.

Shares of Garmin fell 8.6% as investors realized that Apple smartphones will be able to replace its GPS products. Nvidia shares rose 1.1% as the company scored a spot in Apple's new MacBooks, replacing AMD's (AMD) graphics processors.

Google shares fell 2.1%. AMD shares were off 3.7%, and Facebook slipped a fraction.SAN FRANCISCO — Apple (AAPL) on Monday announced a refreshed lineup of MacBook computers, enhancements to its Siri personal assistant, Facebook integration, and Apple map software that will replace an offering from rival Google.The announcements at Apple's Worldwide Developers Conference in San Francisco included no big surprises, such as those related to the rumored iPhone 5 and Apple iTV, and Apple shares fell 1.6%.The annual event, however, is targeted to software developers who make apps for its Macintosh computers, iPhones and iPads, rather than to consumers.Apple's new notebook computers include the latest Intel (INTC) chips and Nvidia (NVDA) graphics processors. The redesigned MacBook Pro computers mirror the super-thin design of the MacBook Air.Apple's 15-inch MacBook Pro features a super-high-resolution Retina display, such as those found on the new iPhones and iPad.With Apple's new MacBook Pro notebooks, the company is betting that it can get people interested in buying expensive laptops again."They were able to inject an awful lot of excitement into a price tier that has almost completely gone away," said Ezra Gottheil, an analyst with Technology Business Research. "All of a sudden they've caused a lot of people to think, 'Maybe I can justify spending $2,200 on a notebook PC.'"The MacBook Pro starts at $2,199 and has standard configurations costing as much as $2,799. The new MacBook Pro computers pack a lot of advanced technology, including the latest processors, long battery life, thin chassis and high-resolution screen, he says.The new notebook lineup should increase Apple's average selling prices and the company's PC profit margins, Gottheil said.Apple executives took shots at rival PC makers who are attempting to compete with Apple notebooks with so-called ultrabooks running Microsoft's (MSFT) Windows operating system. Expect to see more ads for ultrabooks when Microsoft releases its Windows 8 operating system this fall.Chides Copycats"Everyone is trying to copy (the MacBook Air)," said Phil Schiller, Apple's senior vice president of worldwide marketing. "But they find it's not so easy."Apple said its latest Mac operating system, Mountain Lion, will be available in July.And Apple previewed its latest mobile device operating system, iOS 6, which will be available in the fall. It includes 600 new features, such as a new Maps app with Apple-designed cartography, turn-by-turn navigation and Flyover view. This feature might have sparked the biggest ovation from the developers, who sold out the presentation in 90 minutes.The company's Siri voice-command software will support more languages and provide access to sports scores, restaurant recommendations and movie listings.Several carmakers, including BMW and Jaguar, have committed to adding a Siri button to their steering wheels within the next 12 months, said Scott Forstall, Apple's senior vice president of iOS software."We want to integrate Siri even better with a car, so we're working with a number of car manufacturers to enable you to use a button right on the steering wheel to talk to Siri," Forstall said. Google (GOOG) on Tuesday said it bought real-time traffic info company Waze, pressing the gas pedal in its battle with Apple to be the top provider of turn-by-turn directions and up-to-the-minute traffic updates. Google reportedly paid more than $1 billion for Israel-based Waze, although the search leader declined to confirm that price or comment beyond its blog post announcing a…

Action camera maker GoPro posted a stellar performance for the holiday shopping season, but its shares whipsawed in late trading Thursday on an executive resignation and disappointing first-quarter earnings guidance. GoPro (GPRO) stock jumped over 4% in after-hours trading immediately after the San Mateo, Calif.-based company reported better-than-expected Q4 results. But shares then turned south and were soon down 4%…
GoPro (GPRO) is taking its own advice and going pro with the video its action cameras produce.

GoPro has partnered with U.K.-based Vislink to develop live wireless high-definition video transmission systems for the professional broadcast market. GoPro wants to give sports fans the perspective of athletes as they are competing.
To date, GoPro videos are shared after a sporting event, such as skiing, surfing, snowboarding or bike racing. GoPro now wants to break into the live sports broadcast game.

GoPro and Vislink will equip GoPro Hero 4 cameras with professional-grade, live, HD broadcast capabilities. The two companies have been working on a transmitter that is small enough to be worn or mounted to provide all new perspectives for people watching their favorite live sports and events, GoPro said in a press release Wednesday.
GoPro will begin showcasing the new system at live events this winter, including Winter X Games 2015 Aspen, which runs Jan. 22-25, and select AMA Monster Energy Supercross events.

GoPro cameras already are used extensively in professional sports and are worn by athletes or mounted on gear during televised events. But, to date, the videos are stuck on memory cards in the cameras. Those memory cards have to be shuttled to production trucks to look back at the action, the San Mateo, Calif.-based company said.
With the new system, broadcasters will be able to incorporate GoPro videos into live TV events.

"Our partnership with Vislink brings a new level of excitement to live broadcast and we can't wait to see what players, broadcasters and fans do with this new innovative solution," GoPro President Tony Bates said in a statement.
GoPro was one of the standouts at last week's Consumer Electronics Show.

While many companies showed off action cameras at the International CES in Las Vegas, GoPro emerged with its mindshare lead intact, Rosenblatt Securities analyst Brian Blair said in a research note. Sony (SNE), Garmin (GRMN), Panasonic and Polaroid were among the companies showing off rival products at the show.
Earlier this week, GoPro stock was slammed by reports that Apple (AAPL) had patented technology for wearable cameras.
JMP analyst Alex Gauna dismissed concerns that Apple could become a competitor to GoPro and reiterated his outperform rating on GoPro stock Wednesday.

The Apple patent pertains more to smartphone and smartwatch use cases, Gauna said, according to Benzinga. He does not think Apple will "make a direct foray" into GoPro's wearable action camera market.

CES saw "a good number of GoPro imitators but none that were able to match the brand energy, performance, use cases, and/or software and social networking value proposition of the Hero lineup," he said.
RELATED:

Stocks groaned lower in hectic early trade Wednesday, following the lead of global markets after China continued letting its currency fall in line with currency market influences.
The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average slumped 1.3% each. The S&P 500 dropped 1.2%.
Volume rose, up 8% on the Nasdaq and 3% higher on the NYSE, compared with volume levels at the same time Tuesday.

The stock market today launched with the S&P 500 tearing a hole in support at its 200-day moving average, around the 2075 level. The index took a quick breath of air above its 50-day line on Monday and Tuesday before dropping back into its repeated pattern of 200-day tests begun June 29. In that time the index has finished two sessions below that line of support, on July 8 and 9. The Nasdaq is trading just below its 50-day moving average.
U.S. economic news was relatively minor, with the Labor Department's June Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey narrowing to 5.24 million unfilled positions vs. 5.35 million open jobs in May.

New York Federal Reserve chief William Dudley, speaking in Rochester, N.Y., said it was early to judge what was going on in China, that the country's currency could have been appreciating alongside the dollar and in need of adjustment.
"Obviously if the Chinese economy is weaker than maybe what the Chinese authorities anticipated, it's probably not inappropriate for the currency to adjust in consequence to that weakness," he said.
The Energy Information Administration reports weekly oil inventories at 10:30 a.m. ET. The Treasury Department reports its July budget at 2 p.m.
The Dow opened almost unanimously lower. Only Chevron (CVX) rose, up 0.2%, aided by a 1% rebound in oil prices. Apple (AAPL), Nike (NKE), JPMorgan (JPM) and Boeing (BA) fell more than 2%.

On the S&P 500, Fossil (FOSL) and Yahoo (YHOO) were worst hit, down 5% each. Fossil reported weaker-than-expected Q2 revenue growth and Q3 guidance. Yahoo's drop is likely attributable to its 384 million share stake in Alibaba, which has said it will spin off at some point as a separately traded entity.

At the top of the S&P 500, banking and payment software technologies firm Fidelity National Information Services (FIS) jumped nearly 6% after announcing it would pay $9.1 billion to acquire SunGard Data Systems. The privately held SunGard had registered for an initial public offering in June. The company reported $4.67 billion debt as of June 30. National reported that the cash-stock deal would create a company with $9.2 billion in combined revenue. Wednesday's gain hoisted shares to just below a 68.99 buy point in a shallow, five-month cup base.

China-based e-retail giant Alibaba (BABA) retreated 7% in opening trade after its second-quarter earnings narrowly topped expectations, while a 28% revenue jump stopped short of projections and the growth of total gross volume slowed to 34%. Management launched a two-year, $4.6 billion share buyback initiative. The loss put shares 40% below their November high and 6% above their September IPO price.

Among leaders, Ambarella (AMBA), a leading developer of video processing chips, skidded 4% lower, to the bottom of the IBD 50 list. Key client GoPro (GPRO) was also 4% lower in early trade. Pioneers of innovative technologies often end up being savaged by new competitors. Apple (AAPL) did not invent the smartphone, but it knocked out early leaders such as BlackBerry (BBRY). Social networking was not invented by Facebook (FB), but pioneering players such as MySpace got crushed. GoPro (GPRO) might be an exception. The 12-year-old company pioneered and remains the standout in…
Like one of its extreme-sports customers, action camera maker GoPro wowed with its third-quarter performance and fourth-quarter guidance.
GoPro (GPRO) late Thursday reported Q3 earnings of 12 cents a share excluding items, compared with 1 cent a share in the same quarter last year. Sales jumped 46% to $280 million.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected GoPro to earn 8 cents a share minus items on sales of $265.6 million.

For the December quarter, the company expects EPS of 67 cents minus items on sales of $565 million, based on the midpoint of its guidance range. If that holds, the 55% sales gain in Q4, its seasonally strongest period, would mark a second straight quarter of acceleration.
Wall Street had been modeling for earnings of 55 cents a share excluding items on sales of $505 million.
Ready For Its Close-Up

GoPro stock rose more than 11% in after-hours trading on Thursday. During the regular session, it climbed 0.5% to 68.25. Ambarella (AMBA), which supplies chips for GoPro cameras, was up about 5% late.
The cameras are popular with surfers, skiers, kayakers, mountain bikers, kiteboarders and other outdoor enthusiasts who want to record their daredevil exploits and share them online.

Content posted on Google's (GOOGL) YouTube in Q3 was up 92% year-over-year, GoPro said. Views on GoPro's YouTube channel were up 99% and video minutes watched on GoPro's YouTube channel were up more than 133% year-over-year.
GoPro went public on June 26 at 24. The stock touched its all-time high of 98.47 on Oct. 7, sparking debate over its value.
Niche Action Hero?

Last week, Oppenheimer analyst Andrew Uerkwitz said the market for action cameras like GoPro's Hero lineup is limited and it will likely remain a niche product. He also cast shade on GoPro's dreams of becoming a lifestyle brand and media company with all the action videos users are taking.
But on Tuesday, Wedbush Securities analyst Michael Pachter said GoPro leads a "nascent and rapidly growing addressable market" as he initiated coverage with an outperform rating.

GoPro's products compete with those from Garmin (GRMN), Sony (SNE) and others in the young market. But Pachter believes GoPro's strong brand enables it to get premium prices for its cameras and accessories.

"The global scale and execution of our Hero4 launch made this the most successful rollout in GoPro's history," GoPro founder and CEO Nicholas Woodman said in a statement Thursday. He said the company is well positioned for "an exciting holiday season."

The San Mateo, Calif.-based company launched a new lineup of action cameras on Sept. 29. They include the top-of-the-line Hero4 for $499 and entry-level Hero for $129. GoPro also unveiled a larger showcase area at Best Buy (BBY) stores nationwide.

GoPro's Q3 results were its second quarterly financial report since its IPO. Wearable devices are poised to become the fastest-selling consumer electronics category of all time, ramping faster than smartphones and tablets, Morgan Stanley predicted in a report Wednesday. Morgan Stanley expects wearable device shipments to increase from 6 million units in 2013 to 248 million in 2017, for a compound annual growth rate of 154%. That's more than double industry estimates,…

GoPro had a picture perfect Monday, unveiling three new action cameras while its stock hit a new high for the fifth straight session.The new top-of-the-line Hero4 Black will sell for $499 — $100 more than the existing Hero3 Black. But GoPro (GPRO) also introduced a $129 entry-level camera.GoPro is the leading producer of wearable and durable high-definition video cameras — the GoPro Hero series — used by surfers, bikers, skiers and other outdoor enthusiasts to record their adventures. It launched its first high-definition video camera in 2009. It also sells mountable and wearable accessories.Picture Perfect"GoPro has become a movement, with strong products and limited competition," said Shebly Seyrafi, an analyst at FBN Securities. "They don't have competitors that are at their level right now."San Mateo, Calif.-based GoPro said it had a 45% share of the U.S. camcorder market in 2013, followed by Sony (SNE) at 24% and Canon (CAJ) at 12%. Other rivals include Garmin (GRMN). Polaroid introduced a $99 mini video camera last week. Seyrafi said various sources place GoPro consistently higher than its competitors.Seyrafi raised his price target on GoPro to 90 from 70 on Monday.GoPro spiked 11% to 90.94 on Monday. That's up 33% over the last five sessions and 279% from its late June IPO price of 24.Ambarella (AMBA), which makes chips for GoPro cameras, rose 6% to 44.45, hitting a new high. That stock is up 641% since its October 2013 IPO price at 6.In the second quarter GoPro said it shipped 854,000 cameras, up 31% a year earlier. Revenue rose 38% to $244.6 million, earning 8 cents a share, minus items.Seyrafi estimates GoPro will ship 4.43 million cameras this year, up 15% from 2013, at an average price of $284. He predicts GoPro will sell 5.4 million units in 2015. That translates to revenue of $1.26 billion this year and $1.53 billion in 2015."We think that the introduction of the low-end device will better cater to the masses, so we raised our unit assumptions accordingly," Seyrafi said.The Hero4 Black delivers twice the performance of its best-selling predecessor and captures cine ma-quality 4K video at 30 frames per second. It also captures 1080p videos at 120 frames per second and can shoot photos with its 12-megapixel sensor. It boasts an entirely redesigned audio system that captures high-fidelity sound with twice the dynamic range of prior models, GoPro said.A second new camera, the Hero4 Silver at $399, can shoot 1080p video at 60 frames per second and 720p footage at 120fps. It's the first GoPro camera with touchscreen controls.GoPro's entry-level camera, at $129, is its cheapest yet. Hero captures high-quality 1080p video at 30fps and 720p video at 60fps. All three cameras are slated to be available starting Sunday.Supply Issues?JPMorgan analyst Paul Coster in a Friday research note called GoPro's stock overvalued. Retail checks show that the company has been dealing with sold-out products throughout the quarter, he said, indicating that demand is outstripping supply for its cameras.Seyrafi said he's not concerned about supply issues, believing GoPro has planned for a robust Q4 with contract manufacturers.GoPro sells its products in more than 100 countries and via more than 25,000 retail outlets. Sales outside of the U.S. represented 46% of revenue.GoPro has sponsored channels on YouTube, Twitter (TWTR), Instagram and Facebook (FB).

As Apple prepares to enter the wearable device market, it faces big hurdles to consumer adoption of such devices.A recent survey of consumers in the U.S. and U.K. by CCS Insight revealed that awareness of wearable devices is high, but ownership is low. Many consumers indicated that they didn't see the need for a smartwatch or were put off by high prices.The CCS survey found that 75% of respondents are aware of smartwatches and fitness bands. Last year, 63% of respondents knew about smartwatches and 54% knew about fitness bands.This year's survey showed that 6% own and use a fitness tracker and 7% own but no longer use one. The same survey showed that 3% own and use a smartwatch and 2% own but no longer use one.On Tuesday, Apple (AAPL) is widely expected to unveil a smartwatch-fitness band, which has been dubbed the iWatch or iBand. Most analysts don't expect the device to hit the market until late this year or early next.Many people surveyed by CCS Insight said that they hadn't bought a smartwatch because they didn't see the value in it and the prices were too high.As for fitness bands, a large number of respondents indicated that measuring sporting activity was of less interest than tracking health and well-being factors such as sleep and heart rate.The consumer electronics industry needs to do a better job of educating consumers about the benefits of wearable devices, CCS Insight analyst George Jijiashvili said in a statement.Consumers also indicated a desire for a hybrid smartwatch-fitness band, CCS reported. It's very likely that the smartwatch market will cannibalize the fitness band market, the research firm said.Shipments of smart wearables are expected to grow from 9.7 million units in 2013 to 135 million in 2018, CCS Insight said in a separate report. It forecasts shipments of 22 million wearable devices this year.CCS predicts that wrist-worn devices will account for 87% of wearables shipped in 2018 — comprising 68 million smartwatches and 50 million smart bands with no screen or with a minimal, one-line display.The top two makers of fitness bands are Fitbit and Jawbone, with new entrant Garmin (GRMN) chasing third place, research firm Canalys reported last month.Samsung leads the smartwatch market with its Gear devices, followed by Pebble and Sony (SNE), Canalys said.The smartwatch market has been ramping up lately with new devices from Asus, LG Electronics and Motorola, all of which use Google's (GOOGL) Android Wear operating system.RELATED:Round smartwatches a trend with LG, Motorola, Samsung on board .

In Apple's biggest product launch event since the death of its legendary co-founder and CEO Steve Jobs, Apple (AAPL) on Tuesday unveiled a family of smartwatches, a mobile e-payment service and two larger screen iPhone 6 smartphones. Apple's smartwatch, called Apple Watch, features a new user interface and specially designed apps for viewing on the small wrist screen. It also…

Garmin (GRMN) stock jumped Wednesday after the maker of navigation, fitness and outdoor recreation devices beat Wall Street's targets for the fourth quarter.Garmin shares surged on the stock market today, up 7.3% to 54.15 after nearly hitting a buy point and a more than six-month high. Garmin stock has been consolidating over the past 29 weeks and has a buy point of 56.29.Garmin earned 73 cents a share excluding items, down 1% from the year-earlier quarter, on sales of $861 million, up 10%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected the Olathe, Kan.-based company to earn 57 cents a share on sales of $793 million.The company's largest product segment, fitness devices, saw sales rise 20% to $274 million. Its second-largest group, automotive, saw sales fall 17% to $227 million and was the only one of the company's five segments to decline in Q4.IBD'S TAKE: Garmin stock has a middling IBD Composite Rating of 52, meaning it has outperformed 52% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. It is ranked No. 4 out of 10 stocks in IBD's Consumer Products-Electronic industry group. To see which companies lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Garmin's outdoor segment posted the strongest growth, with sales up 46% to $175 million. Aviation sales rose 13% to $117 million and marine sales climbed 19% to $67 million.Garmin's gross profit margin improved to 54.7% in Q4 from 52.9% in the year-earlier quarter.For 2017, Garmin expects to earn $2.65 a share, down 6%, on sales of $3.02 billion, unchanged. The company sees continued growth in outdoor, fitness, marine and aviation offset by ongoing declines in the automotive navigation device business.While Garmin reported strong sales of wearable devices for fitness and sports enthusiasts, rival Fitbit (FIT) has been struggling with sales of activity trackers. Fitbit is due to report Q4 results after the market close Wednesday."2016 was a remarkable year of growth driven by strong sales in our outdoor, fitness, marine and aviation segments," Garmin CEO Cliff Pemble said in a statement. "Entering 2017, we see additional growth opportunities ahead and we are well positioned to seize these opportunities with a strong lineup of great products."RELATED:Fitbit Deemed Unfit By Several Wall Street FirmsGarmin Has Crossed Over To The Income SideChip Sector Remains Strong As Recent Earnings Impress

OK, we get it: The robots are coming. From drone warfare to self-checkout lines at the grocery store, the change is clear. Sales of automated industrial "robots" rose 15% year-over-year in 2015, to reach an annual record of 253,748 units, according to the International Federation of Robotics. Those units were valued at $11 billion, 9% more than the year before.…

PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) and outdoor- and fitness-device maker Garmin (GRMN) received stock upgrades Monday, while action-camera maker GoPro (GPRO) was downgraded to sell.Wells Fargo Securities analyst Maynard Um turned positive on HP stock Monday, raising his rating to outperform from market perform. He said HP's core business has stabilized and its growth opportunities are shaping up nicely.Um raised his valuation range on the stock to 20-to-22, from 15-to-16.50.HP stock was up a fraction, to 17.30, at the closing bell on the stock market today. The stock broke out of a cup base with a buy point of 16.35 on Feb. 14.IBD'S TAKE: HP stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 67, meaning it has outperformed 67% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. But it ranks No. 5 out of 14 stocks in IBD's Computer-Hardware & Peripherals industry group. To see which company leads the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Elsewhere among personal technology stocks, Goldman Sachs upgraded Garmin to neutral from sell and downgraded GoPro to sell from neutral.Goldman Sachs analyst Simona Jankowski raised her 12-month price target on Garmin to 52 from 48.Garmin stock was up 0.5% to 51.76 at the close Monday."A key part of our thesis — deceleration in the fitness business — has now played out, with the company guiding for fitness growth to decelerate to 5% in 2017 after 24% growth in 2016," she said. "We no longer see downside to consensus estimates, and expect a return to growth in 2018."Garmin posted strong holiday-season results, helped by a weak performance by fitness device rival Fitbit (FIT). Unlike Fitbit, Garmin has a diversified business. In addition to making activity trackers like Fitbit, Garmin makes sports watches, gadgets for outdoor enthusiasts, and navigation devices for the automotive, maritime and aviation markets.Fitbit on Monday introduced an upgraded version of its Fitbit Alta fitness band that now includes heart-rate tracking. It described the Fitbit Alta HR as "the world's slimmest wrist-based, continuous heart-rate tracking device." It also features automatic exercise recognition, sleep tracking, battery life of up to seven days and smart notifications. The device will be available in early April and retail for $149.95.Fitbit stock lost 1.2% to end the day at 6.Jankowski turned bearish on GoPro, slashing her price target on the stock to 6 from 9.50.GoPro tumbled nearly 8% to finish the regular session at 8.14. Intraday, its shares hit an all-time low of 7.95."GoPro faces significant challenges following saturation of its core action cameras market, product rollout issues in the holiday season, and a disappointing entry into the drone market," Jankowski said in a report. "We expect GoPro to continue to struggle fundamentally."RELATED:HP Breaks Out On Q1 Beat; Fitbit Up On In-Line Q4Garmin Beats Q4 Targets On Strong Fitness, Outdoor Device SalesGoPro Stock Goes Lower On Q4 Sales Miss, Weak Guidance

Hot tech IPO Snap (SNAP) was initiated at underperform by Needham & Co., UBS upgraded Netflix (NFLX) stock to buy, and Well Fargo upgraded printer and laptop computer-maker HP Inc. (HPQ) to outperform.Needham & Co. initiated coverage of the social media firm's stock with an "underperform" rating, noting the company's total addressable market is 80% smaller than Facebook. "SNAP has no clear path to profitability before 2020," added the Needham report.Shares of Snap rose as high as 28.25, but reversed to trade down 8.3% at 24.84 in afternoon trade on the stock market today.RELATED:Comcast Snaps Up Stake In Mobile Messaging App SnapchatUBS upgraded Netflix to buy with a price target of 175. "We see upside to 1Q17 subscriber guidance given momentum in Europe and Latin America, and modest improvements in Japan," said the UBS report.Shares in Netflix rose 1.8% to 141.70 intraday and are extended after clearing 129.39 technical buy point from a cup-with-handle entry in January.RELATED:Netflix Hovers Below All-Time High As It Nears 100 Million SubscribersWell Fargo upgraded HP to outperform from market perform, saying its margin improvement may be overlooked.Shares in HP fell 0.3% to 17.29. Last month HP cleared a 16.35 buy point from a cup-with-handle chart pattern.RELATED:HP Breaks Out On Q1 Beat; Fitbit Up On In-Line Q4RBC Capital hiked its price target on Kite Pharma (KITE) to 95 from 85. Kite could be a takeover target of Gilead Sciences (GILD) or Roche, speculated RBC Capital in a report. Kite's lymphoma drug is under review by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Kite recently reported strong results for its drug, known as KTE-C19, for treating the lymphatic system cancer known as diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.Kite shares were up 1.7% to 73.79.RELATED:Kite Pharma Cancer Drug Poised For Approval In 2017, Says RBCIn other analyst moves, Goldman Sachs upgraded Garmin (GRMN) to neutral; Macquarie Research upgraded Expedia (EXPE) to outperform, with a price target of 144, up from 123; Instinet increased its price target on Square (SQ) to 21 from 18. BMO Capital Markets upgraded FedEx (FDX) to outperform.

Consumer electronics giant Apple (AAPL) gained ground in the wearables market in the fourth quarter, thanks to its Apple Watch Series 1 and Series 2, research firm IDC said Thursday.Apple was the third-largest maker of wearable devices in the December quarter, with 13.6% market share by unit shipments. It shipped 4.6 million Apple Watches in the fourth quarter, up 13% from the same period a year ago, IDC said.Apple doesn't disclose how many smartwatches it sells. The consensus estimate among Wall Street analysts was that Apple sold 4.9 million watches in the holiday sales quarter.Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook touted Apple Watch sales, without giving actual numbers, on a conference call with analysts Jan. 31."It was also our best quarter ever for Apple Watch, both units and revenue, with holiday demand so strong that we couldn't make enough," he said.IBD'S TAKE: Apple stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 89, meaning it has outperformed 89% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more information on Apple, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.IDC said the Apple Watch Series 1 and Series 2 devices "proved to be a magnificent success for the company" in the fourth quarter.Apple stock slipped 0.59% to 138.96 on the stock market today. That ended what had been a four-day winning streak, though early in the trading session, the stock edged up to an all-time high of 140.28.Fitness band maker Fitbit (FIT) led the wearables market in the fourth quarter with 6.5 million units shipped, down 23% year over year, IDC said. Fitbit's market share dipped to 19.2% from 29% in the year-ago quarter.Xiaomi, a maker of low-cost activity trackers based in China, came in second place in the fourth quarter with 5.2 million units shipped, up 96% year over year, IDC said. Its market share rose to 15.2% from 9.1% a year earlier.After Apple, Garmin (GRMN) placed fourth with 6.2% market share and Samsung fifth with 5.6%, IDC said.Total wearables shipments rose 17% to a record high 33.9 million units in the fourth quarter, IDC said in a press release. For the full year, wearables shipments rose 25% to 102.4 million units.RELATED:Apple Stock Gets Two Price-Target Increases, Hovers Near HighFitbit's Holiday Season Was Even Worse Than Feared; More Losses Ahead

Wearable fitness device maker Fitbit (FIT) late Wednesday reported worse-than-expected December-quarter results, even though it preannounced a dismal holiday shopping season on Jan. 30. It also guided analysts lower for the current quarter.Fitbit stock was flat in after-hours trading on the stock market today, but this was after falling 2.7% to 5.88 in the regular session. Shares have traded under 10 since Nov. 3, after the company gave disappointing guidance and posted disappointed Q3 results.Results: Fitbit lost 56 cents a share excluding items in the fourth quarter, swinging from a year-earlier profit of 35 cents a share. Sales fell 19% to $574 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Fitbit to lose 50 cents a share ex items on sales of $576 million. Fitbit's results were within the lowered guidance range the San Francisco-based company provided last month, but missed Wall Street's consensus estimates.Q1 Guidance: For the current quarter, Fitbit expects to lose 19 cents a share ex items on sales of $280 million, at the midpoint of its guidance. Wall Street was modeling Fitbit to lose 15 cents a share on sales of $307 million.Full-Year Guidance: For 2017, Fitbit is targeting an adjusted loss of 33 cents a share on sales of $1.6 billion. Wall Street was looking for a loss of 32 cents a share and sales of $1.59 billion.Fitbit's Q4 numbers came hours after rival Garmin (GRMN) reported better-than-expected holiday quarter results thanks to strong sales of sports and fitness wearable devices."Our 10-year history of building this category, coupled with our powerful brand and engaged global community gives us confidence we are making the right investments to support our vision and drive long-term success," Fitbit CEO James Park said in the company's earnings release. "We will leverage our leadership position, recently acquired talent and (intellectual property), and the valuable data we collect to improve demand and continue to set the pace of innovation for the industry through more personalized experiences, deeper insights and guidance, expansion into new categories and deeper integration within the health care system."RELATED:Fitbit Deemed Unfit By Several Wall Street FirmsFitbit Slashes Expectations For Q4, Year Ahead; Shifts To Smartwatches

GoPro (GPRO) shares jumped on Thursday after the maker of action cameras said its first-quarter revenue would be at the high end of its guidance range and it announced a new round of layoffs and cost cuts to return to profitability.But the struggling consumer electronics firm had trouble convincing Wall Street as it gave its first-quarter update after the market close Wednesday, the same day its stock hit an all-time low of 7.15.GoPro shot up nearly 16% to 8.51 on the stock market today. The San Mateo, Calif.-based company went public at 24 in June 2014 and climbed as high as 98.47 in October of that year.Analysts were mixed on the company's update. Citigroup upgraded GoPro stock to neutral from sell. Stifel kept its hold rating on GoPro, but dropped its price target to 9 from 10.GoPro said its first-quarter revenue would be at the upper end of its previously announced range of $190 million to $210 million. It also repeated its target of full-year unadjusted, or non-GAAP, profitability."We're determined that GoPro's financial performance match the strength of our products and brand. Importantly, expense reductions preserve our product roadmap and we are tracking to full-year non-GAAP profitability in 2017," GoPro founder and Chief Executive Nicholas Woodman said in a statement.GoPro expects to reduce operating expenses through a combination of cuts to program costs and head count, eliminating about 270 positions, or 17% of its workforce. It is the company's third head count reduction since January 2016.Dougherty analyst Charles Anderson said GoPro didn't go far enough with its latest cost cuts. He rates the stock as sell with a price target of 5.IBD'S TAKE: GoPro stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 9, meaning it has been outperformed by 91% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more information on GoPro stock and its peers, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brad Erickson maintained his sector weight rating on GoPro."While GoPro's preannouncement was likely aimed at quelling the shorts, questions remain around new product innovation amid such drastic cost cuts," Erickson said in a report. "Management reiterating double-digit growth in 2017 makes it hard to argue for further near-term downside, but we need better visibility into demand before changing our more neutral stance on the shares."GoPro management cited the company's new Karma flying-camera drone for the first-quarter revenue upside.GoPro ranks No. 7 out of nine stocks in IBD's Consumer Products-Electronic industry group. The top company in the group is GPS navigation and outdoor electronics maker Garmin (GRMN).RELATED:This Big Dividend Play Has Accelerating Sales Growth And $2.3 Billion CashHP Upgraded To Buy; GoPro Cut To Sell; Garmin Moved To NeutralGoPro Stock Goes Lower On Q4 Sales Miss, Weak Guidance

Personal computer and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) on Thursday saw its shares spike after beating Wall Street's fiscal first-quarter targets. Meanwhile, wearable fitness device maker Fitbit (FIT) appeared to calm investors with Q4 results that came within its lowered guidance range.At least seven Wall Street analysts raised their price targets on HP stock after the company's Q1 report late Wednesday. But of those seven, five reiterated neutral or equivalent ratings on the stock. Two were bullish: FBN Securities and Morgan Stanley.FBN analyst Shebly Seyrafi upgraded HP stock to outperform from sector perform and raised his price target to 19 from 15. Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty reiterated her overweight rating on HP stock and upped her price target to 19 from 16.IBD'S TAKE: HP stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 67, meaning it has outperformed 67% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. But it ranks No. 5 out of 14 stocks in IBD's Computer-Hardware and Peripherals industry group. To see which companies lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.HP broke out of a nine-week cup base with a buy point of 16.35 on Thursday. Shares of the Palo Alto, Calif.-based company rose as much as 9.9% to a two-year high of 17.80 in intraday trading on the stock market today. HP stock closed the session at 17.60, up 8.6%.Seyrafi turned positive on HP because of the company's solid execution and "excellent free cash flow metrics." HP PC sales are benefiting from innovative products and its printer supplies business is showing signs of stabilization, he said in his research report.Patrick Moorhead, an analyst with Moor Insights & Strategy, said HP's PC business is benefiting from consolidation in the market, which has left three big vendors: Lenovo, HP and Dell Technologies (DVMT). HP also was smart to shift to premium Windows PCs in the consumer and commercial markets, he said in a report.Fitbit stock rose on Thursday after its December quarter report was better than feared. Fitbit shares rose 3.2% to 6.07 Thursday.Most analysts maintained a cautious tone on the stock, which has been hammered by slowing sales of wearable fitness devices.Cowen analyst John Kernan reiterated his market perform rating on Fitbit, but cut his price target to 7 from 9."Guidance for 2017 implies weak sales, down 26% year over year at the midpoint, additional gross margin contraction and expense management," Kernan said.While Fitbit leads the fitness tracker market, it has been ceding share to Garmin (GRMN) and other brands, he said in a report.On Wednesday, Garmin reported better-than-expected Q4 results thanks to strong wearable device sales.Fitbit management is focused on entering the smartwatch market now, leveraging its learnings from the Fitbit Blaze fitness watch and its recent acquisitions, including Pebble. But the company will face tough competition from Apple (AAPL) and others in the smartwatch business, Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy said in a report. She rates Fitbit stock as underweight with a price target of 5.RELATED:Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stocks

Sellers were kept at bay again in afternoon trading Wednesday as the Dow Jones industrial average eked out a small gain, helped by a 4% pop in DuPont (DD).Dupont's merger with Dow Chemical (DOW) is on track after the Wall Street Journal reported that European regulators were set to approve the deal, first announced in late 2015. Shares of Dow Chemical jumped nearly 5%.The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite edged lower by 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly lower than Tuesday's levels.In economic news, existing-home sales in January hit a 10-year high. IBD's home-building group was up 1.2% early, but the gain faded to 0.1%.In related news, homebuilder Toll Brothers (TOL) gapped up sharply on better than expected earnings. It's still well within buy range from a 33.58 entry.The minutes from the Feb. 1 Federal Reserve meeting will be released at 2 p.m. ET.In the stock market today, restaurant stocks were under pressure after Papa John's (PZZA) and Texas Roadhouse (TXRH) reported earnings late Tuesday. Both stocks gapped down in price, falling 6% and 13%, respectively.IBD's restaurant group was down 1.5% in afternoon trading. A healthy economy is usually good news for restaurant stocks, but the industry is facing competition from food-delivery services like GrubHub (GRUB)Garmin (GRMN) was another big earnings winners, up 7% to 54.28. It's still in buy range from a 53.67 buy point.Inside the IBD 50, Alibaba (BABA) rose nearly 3% to 104.97 as it vies for a breakout from a cup-with-handle base with a 104.67 buy point.After the close, watch for earnings from Weibo (WB) and Tesla (TSLA). Weibo was mostly unchanged ahead of the results while Tesla gave back nearly 1%.Software name Splunk (SPLK) has been in rally mode in the run-up to its earnings report Thursday after the close. It's on the verge of clearing a long consolidation with a 65.85 buy point.RELATED:Mobileye Earnings Growth Accelerates; Tesla On TapBest Stocks To Buy And Watch

Stocks opened lower Wednesday as earnings reports and a reversal in oil prices helped drag on early trade.The Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq fell 0.2% as the S&P 500 gave up 0.3%.IBD 50 stock Mobileye (MBLY) climbed nearly 4% after reporting a 47% earnings gain and a 46% increase in revenue for its fourth quarter. Both numbers beat consensus estimates. The company had also announced Tuesday it would partner with BMW to develop advanced mapping technology for release on 2018 BMW models. Mobileye shares are now extended above a 45.03 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Garmin (GRMN) charted a 9% gain on the heels of a solid fourth-quarter surprise. The maker of hand-held and installed global positioning systems reported earnings and revenue that topped analysts views by wide margins. Full-year earnings guidance met, and revenue forecasts were above, targets.  The stock gapped above a buy point at 53.67 in an irregular base.Toll Brothers (TOL) framed up a 6% gain at the open. The Horsham, Pa.-based builder of luxury homes reported a surprise earnings gain and a milder-than-expected drop in revenue in its fiscal first quarter. Management also raised the midpoint of its projected full-year deliveries by 100 units, with average prices between $775,000 and $825,000. Toll broke out past the 33.58 buy point in a flat base.Nationstar Mortgage Holdings (NSM) edged a fraction lower at the open following its fourth-quarter results. The mortgage servicing agency is forming a flat base with a 19.79 buy point.France-based online advertising innovator Criteo (CRTO) fell 4% as investors looked past a solid fourth-quarter performance and focused on weak first-quarter guidance. Shares are just below the 44.24 buy point of a breakout Jan. 11.Oil prices reversed and dropped more than 1%, sending West Texas Intermediate back below $54 a barrel. The dollar was mixed. Rising bonds trimmed the 10-year yield 2 basis points to 2.41%.January existing home sales are expected from the National Association of Realtors at 10 a.m. ET. Minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's Jan. 31-Feb. 1 meeting come out at 2 p.m.Federal Reserve Board member Jerome Powell speaks at 1 p.m. ET.RELATED: Mobileye Earnings Growth Accelerates; Tesla On TapCan The Stock Market Defy The Law Of Gravity?

It's rare to see tech companies emerge on the IBD Dividend Leaders screen, but these are not the same tech companies they once were. Former big winners, Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Garmin (GRMN) no longer have the same torrid growth they once offered and so attract investors with dividend yields instead. The two former highfliers have dividend yields of 3.3% and 4.1%,…

Harley-Davidson (HOG) shares dropped after it reported second-quarter profit early Wednesday that beat estimates, but its sales came up short. The top U.S. motorcycle maker isn't alone. Automakers General Motors (GM), Ford Motor (F)and Chrysler Group, which posted surprisingly strong sales early in the year, Wednesday reported lower-than-expected July sales. Harley-Davidson's earnings per share climbed 32% to $1.07 in Q2,…
A rival’s slew of national Black Friday deals has make for a dark Tuesday for local daily deals site Groupon (GPRN).

Shares of the pioneer in the increasingly crowded coupon space fell 10% Monday and were down another 15% today, after a top rival LivingSocial on Monday announced coupon offers with big names, including Verizon Wireless  (VZ), Electronic Arts  (ERTS), Skechers USA  (SKX) and OfficeMax  (OMX).
Groupon shares closed at 20.07 today — barely above its $20 IPO price from earlier this month.

Groupon and LivingSocial have mostly focused on hyperlocal deals — half-off at local restaurants, deals at nail salons or discounts for cooking classes. But that space is growing crowded, with daily offers now from giants such as retailer Amazon (AMZN) and review site Yelp, which is considering its own IPO.

Groupon too is offering some national deals from retailers such as teen clothier American Apparel   (APP), florist 1-800 Flowers.com  (FLWS), and navigation system maker Garmin (GRMN). More are coming for Black Friday and Cyber Monday, spokeswoman Kelsey O’Neill told IBD.

The successful Groupon launch — it popped 30% in its Nov. 4 debut — signaled renewed investor appetite, after an IPO dry spell. But its volatility shows the vulnerability to competition in the deals space, said Anupam Palit, an analyst with GreenCrest Capital Management.
Customer acquisition costs can be high. And keeping customers can be difficult.
And some large retailers are starting to offer deals to their consumers directly, cutting out the middle-man.

"Everyone’s offering their own deals now. Big brands are realizing that I don’t need to offer it through a third-party," he said.A rival’s slew of national Black Friday deals has make for a dark Tuesday for local daily deals site Groupon (GPRN).Shares of the pioneer in the increasingly crowded coupon space fell 10% Monday and were down another 15% today, after a top rival LivingSocial on Monday announced coupon offers with big names, including Verizon Wireless  (VZ), Electronic Arts  (ERTS), Skechers USA  (SKX) and OfficeMax  (OMX).Groupon shares closed at 20.07 today — barely above its $20 IPO price from earlier this month.Groupon and LivingSocial have mostly focused on hyperlocal deals — half-off at local restaurants, deals at nail salons or discounts for cooking classes. But that space is growing crowded, with daily offers now from giants such as retailer Amazon (AMZN) and review site Yelp, which is considering its own IPO.Groupon too is offering some national deals from retailers such as teen clothier American Apparel   (APP), florist 1-800 Flowers.com  (FLWS), and navigation system maker Garmin (GRMN). More are coming for Black Friday and Cyber Monday, spokeswoman Kelsey O’Neill told IBD.The successful Groupon launch — it popped 30% in its Nov. 4 debut — signaled renewed investor appetite, after an IPO dry spell. But its volatility shows the vulnerability to competition in the deals space, said Anupam Palit, an analyst with GreenCrest Capital Management.Customer acquisition costs can be high. And keeping customers can be difficult.And some large retailers are starting to offer deals to their consumers directly, cutting out the middle-man."Everyone’s offering their own deals now. Big brands are realizing that I don’t need to offer it through a third-party," he said.

The stock indexes showed virtually no hesitation Thursday as they tacked on moderate gains. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each rose 0.7%, and the NYSE composite added 0.6%. Volume fell on the NYSE and rose on the Nasdaq. The NYSE composite regained its 50-day moving average. The other indexes climbed above that key level Wednesday. Economic news Thursday was mixed.…
IBD's 20 Rules: An Investor's Corner Series
Thirteenth In A Series
"Owner-operated" is always a good sign, whether stenciled on a big-rig truck or a leading stock.

In either case, it means those at the controls have a higher-than-usual interest in piloting the vehicle safely and profitably. In stocks, there are a number of ways to track down the percentage of outstanding shares owned by management.

The company descriptions in the Weekly IBD 50 lists include percentage of management ownership. In the most recent list, management of both Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and Arcos Dorados (ARCO) owned more than 30% of shares outstanding. IPG Photonics (IPGP) took the prize, however, with 42% of shares owned by company executives.

The Big Cap 20 list also shows management ownership. By nature, big-cap stocks are generally older and have been public longer with much larger numbers of shares. Management naturally owns smaller portions. The biggest share of management ownership on the most recent Big Cap 20 list was Amazon.com (AMZN), with a 20% share in management's keeping.

You can also find management ownership data using the E-Tables tool at investors.com. Just click on the "View Expanded Stock Data" function in the red band just below the Index tabs. This tool also allows you to sort by management ownership to quickly find stocks with strong management holdings.

Management held a 31% piece of stun gun maker Taser (TASR) when it started its epic run in April 2003. The stock ran up more than 4,000% in 12 months. By the peak, management ownership had dropped to 15%. The stock has never come close to that high again. Today, management holds 8% of the company's shares.

This is not to say that companies with lesser management ownership don't do well. Stocks often excel with minuscule management-share figures. And you would not want to use the percentage of management ownership as a sole or even a leading metric in choosing a stock. But it can act as a reinforcing piece of data.
So as you line up your pluses and minuses in fundamental research, don't ignore this factor, which suggests management is thoroughly vested in seeing that share prices do well.

Another good example is Garmin Industries (GRMN). The innovative developer of global positioning equipment came public in December of 2000. When it cleared its initial base two years later, management owned 47% of the company's shares.
The stock climbed more than 900% over the next five years. When it peaked in October 2007, management still owned 47%. Today management's share is still healthy, but a much more modest 23%.

Stocks climbed for the second straight session Wednesday, as the market shook off a big jump in energy prices. Volume rose on the NYSE but dipped on the Nasdaq. The NYSE indexes fared best. The Dow industrials jumped 1.6%. The S&P 500 and NYSE composite both vaulted 1.7%. The Nasdaq settled for a 0.4% gain. September crude rallied as much…
When studying bases, price and volume action is key, but there's something else that investors should study  how a stock is trading relative to the general market.

You can do just that by checking the stock's Relative Strength line. The line can help you analyze bases. It can also help you flag a weak breakout, or otherwise provide confirmation of strength or weakness.

The RS line compares a stock's price performance to the S&P 500, a broad proxy for the general market. It does not plot the stock's Relative Price Strength Rating, which is a different performance gauge.
Performance Yardstick
Stocks don't trade in a vacuum; you have to measure their performance against a reliable yardstick.
If your stock is up 10% year-to-date, you might think that's great. But if the S&P 500 is up 15%, then that's not so good. In this case, the stock is underperforming and the RS line will trend lower.
On the other hand, if a stock is vastly outperforming, say up 25% while the S&P 500 is up just 5%, then its RS line will trend sharply higher.
During corrections, stocks that hold up well also may have upward- sloping RS lines. And if a stock is performing roughly in line with the market, its RS line will be flat.
You can find the RS line on IBD Charts at Investors.com. It's the blue line commonly just under the price bars. You can view the line in both the daily and weekly charts.
The RS line can point you to sound bases. When scouting chart patterns, look for stocks that have RS lines near former highs or at least not sharply lower than past highs.
In short, you want to avoid stocks whose RS lines significantly lag the price.
It's a bullish sign when the RS line makes new highs before the stock breaks out of its base.
In the week ended Nov. 8, 2002, Garmin (GRMN) pushed north for the second straight week in strong volume. Its RS line shot to new-high ground, while the stock sat 8% below a 52-week high .
A few weeks later, the stock cleared the base and jumped 32% before pulling back to its 10-week moving average.
In another example, VeriFone Holdings (PAY) came public in April 2005. By July, it more than doubled and started forming its first base 1.
In the week ended Oct. 21, the stock regained its 10-week line, while its RS line rallied to an all-time high ahead of its price 2.
The next week, VeriFone cleared its 12-week base 3 and jumped 50% by May 2006 .
Generally, the RS line should move in tandem with price. When a stock rallies to a new high, the line should confirm the move. Otherwise, that's a bad sign.
Important For Breakouts
During breakouts, this is especially key. A lagging RS line at the breakout often leads to price declines.
Pfizer (PFE) cleared a 7 1/2-month base in the week ended Feb. 6, 2004. But its RS line badly lagged while the stock formed the right side of the pattern.
As Pfizer topped levels from the left side of the base, its RS line moved higher, but was nowhere near old highs from June 2003. The stock's breakout soon turned into a breakdown.
Investors.com's Screen of the Day runs a list of stocks whose RS lines are making or are near new highs every few weeks.

A rapid rise in the use of touch-screens for tablet computers, smartphones and other gear has translated into heavy demand for chips that can power the screens.
Among the beneficiaries is Cypress Semiconductor (CY). The company supplies touch-screen chips and other high-performance, mixed-signal, programmable solutions to a variety of end markets.
In years past, Cypress was best known for its SRAM chips that help computers perform core memory functions.
But thanks to a series of design wins, the company's touch-screen gear, including its TrueTouch family of products, has become the biggest revenue generator.

During a conference call with analysts following Cypress' first-quarter earnings report, Chief Financial Officer Brad Buss said TrueTouch became the company's "largest individual product family" during the quarter.
"It was bigger than our synchronous SRAM business, which has been the 'Big Daddy' for quite a few years," Buss said. "Design activity continues to be really strong."
The rapid ascent of Cypress' TrueTouch business is the direct result of shifts in consumer trends, analysts say. That shift includes buying fewer PCs and more tablet computers and smartphones.

"Cypress' products are used in a variety of areas, but the TrueTouch used in the booming tablet market as well as smartphones is the hottest source of growth," analyst Bill Wilton recently noted in a report for Zacks.com.
Many Uses
In addition to smartphones and tablets, touch-screens are becoming a bigger presence in cameras, IP phones, automotive dashboards, e-books and GPS devices.
Cypress supplies touch-screen chips for use in Research in Motion's (RIMM) PlayBook as well as Samsung Electronics' Galaxy series of devices.
Rising demand for touch-screen chips has translated into a big financial rebound for Cypress.
In 2010, the company grew sales 31% year-over-year, ending a run of three straight years of lower sales. Annual earnings rose more than ninefold in 2010 after declining 84% the prior year.
Cypress shares touched a record high of 23.95 on May 31.
The outlook for 2011 looks equally promising as Cypress looks to take advantage of a market with very little competition or pricing pressure.

The company competes with Atmel (ATML) and Synaptics (SYNA) in the touch-screen market. Like Cypress, both of those companies have notched robust financial returns over the last several quarters, though analysts expect Synaptics to face lower sales and earnings beginning this quarter.
In contrast, analysts see Cypress continuing to log double-digit profit and revenue gains well into next year even as some experts worry that the overall chip market is headed for a down cycle.

"Whereas SRAM was a drag on Cypress exiting the 2001-02 down cycle, we expect Cypress' proprietary products (including TrueTouch) to drive a steeper revenue recovery in coming quarters," Citigroup analyst Glen Yeung noted in a report.
While much of the optimism stems from the smartphone sector, Cypress officials also have pointed to strength in other end markets.

During the Q1 conference call, Chief Executive T.J. Rodgers conceded that cell phones are the "big-volume, much sought-after wins." But, he added, Cypress is also focusing on wins in digital cameras, auto dashboards, GPS devices, printers, e-books and tablets.
"We're pushing all of those — not just cell phones," Rodgers said.
The company's design wins last quarter included deals with GPS makers Garmin (GRMN) and TomTom, Cisco's (CSCO) IP phone division, Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) printer division and Sony's camera unit.

Cypress logged Q1 revenue of $233.2 million. That was up 15% from the prior year and above estimates for $228.9 million. Earnings climbed 41% to 24 cents a share, a penny above views. It was Cypress' ninth straight earnings beat.
Much of the top-line growth came from the TrueTouch unit. Its revenue climbed nearly 40% quarter-over-quarter and more than 200% year-over-year.
"Cypress' TrueTouch family of touch-screen controllers continues to gain traction with handset, tablet, and e-reader manufacturers," Yeung noted.
Growth Expectations
Cypress expects the touch-screen chip segment to more than double in size by the end of the year.
"There has been very strong growth in handsets, and we also are starting to see nice contributions in our large-screen formats," CFO Buss said during the conference call.
In terms of risks, JPMorgan analyst Christopher Danely noted in a report that Cypress' gross margins fell 70 basis points sequentially, to 55.2% from 55.9%, during the 2010 fourth quarter.

"That was below our estimate of 56.0% due to lower utilization rates," Danely wrote. "We expect 2Q11 gross margins to remain roughly flat quarter-over-quarter at 55.0% due to higher utilization offset by higher costs."

Cypress is due to report second-quarter earnings on July 21. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect profit of 30 cents a share, up from 24 cents a year earlier. Full-year profit should rise 35% this year and 17% in 2012.A rapid rise in the use of touch-screens for tablet computers, smartphones and other gear has translated into heavy demand for chips that can power the screens.Among the beneficiaries is Cypress Semiconductor (CY). 5:15 p.m. Update: Economic worries sent stocks sliding Wednesday and extended their recent losing streak to four sessions.
Goldman Sachs lowered its Q3 GDP forecast to 2.7% from 3%. New-home sales fell for the first time in six months. But durable goods orders, excluding transportation, beat estimates.
The Nasdaq sliced its 50-day moving average, tumbling 2.7%. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 also sliced their 50-day lines, losing 2.4% and 2%, respectively.
Meanwhile, the Dow dropped 1.2%. It's still about 65 points above its 50-day average.
Volume spiked up on the Nasdaq and NYSE.
Many leaders were again under fire.
Fuqi International (FUQI) swooned 12% on more than twice its average trade. The Chinese jewelry maker extended its losing streak to six sessions and slumped to a three-month low.
VanceInfo Technologies (VIT) dumped 11% on about double its normal turnover. The Chinese software developer reports earnings Nov. 17. Analysts see profit rising 8% to 13 cents a share.
Other Chinese issues CNinsure (CISG) and E-House Holdings (EJ) dropped 11% and 7%, respectively.
Elsewhere, Tessera Technologies (TSRA) lost 6% on nearly double its average trade. On Monday, the chip designer fell 8% from a 29.35 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern.
On the upside, Baidu (BIDU) gained 3% on more than twice normal volume. The stock recouped a piece of Tuesday's 11% decline. Baidu was one of three IBD 100 components that rose on the session.

Earnings Thursday: Aetna (AET), American Superconductor (AMSC), Barrick Gold (ABX), CME Group (CME), Colgate-Palmolive (CL), Corinthian Colleges (COCO), Exxon Mobil (XOM), Lubrizol (LZ), Medifast (MED), Newmont Mining (NEM) Nu Skin (NUS), Olympic Steel (ZEUS), Sourcefire (FIRE) and Websense (WBSN).
Data on third-quarter GDP and weekly jobless claims will also be out Thursday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Close Near Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks took a beating Wednesday, closing near the worst levels of the session.
The Nasdaq swooned 2.7%, New York composite 2.4%, S&P 500 2% and Dow 1.2%.
Volume surged on both exchanges. Decliners thrashed advancers by about 9-to-1 on the NYSE and more than 5-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Tire makers, homebuilders, oil, steel and media were the session's worst groups.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Slide In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Indexes slumped to new intraday lows in late trade Wednesday, as an earlier rebound gave way.

The Nasdaq tumbled 2.3%, dragged down by losses in Illumina (ILMN), Apollo Group (APOL) and Garmin (GRMN). Chip issues were also a drag on the Nasdaq. The Philadelphia semiconductor index dropped 2.2% to a one-month low.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite fell 1.9%, the S&P 500 1.5% and the Dow 0.9%.

Ultimate Software Group (ULTI) gapped below its 50-day moving average and shed 9% in heavy trading. Late Tuesday, the maker of human resources and payroll software reported Q3 earnings that met views, but sales missed estimates.

AsiaInfo Holdings (ASIA) fell 5% in heavy trading ahead of its earnings after the close. Analysts see the Chinese software maker's profit rising 50% to 24 cents a share. The stock had been down about 9% earlier.
Compellent Technologies (CML) erased earlier gains and slipped 2% ahead of its Q3 report after the close. The software maker is slated to post a profit of 5 cents a share, up 67% from a year ago.

Elsewhere, China-Biotics (CHBT) pared a 9% gain down to a fraction. Earlier Wednesday, the probiotics product maker said it began production at a new facility and expects sales growth of at least 50% in fiscal 2010.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Bounce Back In Afternoon Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks cut losses after a strong five-year note auction Wednesday afternoon.
The Nasdaq trimmed a 2.1% loss to 1.7%. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 shed 1.5% and 1.1%, respectively.
The Dow lost 0.6%.
Volume continued to track sharply higher on both exchanges.
Garmin (GRMN) gapped down, plunged 17% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The GPS device maker stumbled on news that Google (GOOG) is launching a free navigation system for cell phones.
Homex Development (HXM) gapped below its 50-day moving average and tumbled 11% in heavy trading. Late Tuesday, the Mexican homebuilder reported Q3 earnings below views.
Lubrizol (LZ) fell 5% in fast trade and hovered near its 50-day line. The chemical maker reports earnings Thursday. Analysts are expecting $2.52 a share, up 157% from a year ago.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Hit New Session Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
Rebound efforts faltered, sending stocks to new session lows in early afternoon trading Wednesday.
The Nasdaq dropped 1.8%, NYSE composite 1.6% and S&P 500 1.1%. All three sliced their respective 50-day moving averages.
Meanwhile, the Dow lost 0.5%, but remained above its 50-day line. Gains in AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) cushioned the blue-chip index's fall.
Turnover was tracking sharply higher across the board. Decliners trounced advancers by more than 4-to-1 on the NYSE and over 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Leaders continued to get hit.
Fuqi International (FUQI) slumped 10% to a three-month low. The Chinese jewelry maker now sits 40% off its Sept. 15 record high.

Hi-Tech Pharmacal (HITK) rolled over for the seventh straight session. It tumbled 9% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating weakened to B- from A+ early this month.

Elsewhere, school stocks stumbled on news Apollo Group (APOL) is being investigated by the Securities & Exchange Commission over its revenue recognition practices. Apollo shares gapped down and swooned 16%.
Bridgepoint Education (BPI) shed 8%, Grand Canyon Education (LOPE) dropped 7% and ITT Educational Services (ESI) lost 6%.

On the upside, Visa (V) gapped up and rallied 5% to a 52-week high. Late Tuesday, the firm delivered Q3 results above views and raised its quarterly dividend. Visa's board also approved a $1 billion stock buyback.
12:15 p.m. Update: Major Indexes Fall At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks' losses deepened at midday Wednesday.
The Dow sank 0.3%, the S&P 500 0.9%, the Nasdaq 1.4% and the NYSE composite 1.3%.
Volume swelled across the board. It rose 15% on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.
More high-rated stocks came under heavy selling.
Under Armour (UA) skidded 11% in six times its normal trade. The athletic apparel maker tumbled for the second straight session as investors fretted over the company's fourth-quarter outlook.
CNinsure (CISG) slid 9% in nearly triple its typical turnover. The Chinese property and casualty insurer sliced through its 50-day moving average.
China-based travel services provider Universal Travel (UTA) also violated its 50-day line, falling 9% in heavy volume.
11:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Retain Losses

5:15 p.m. Update: Mark this one down as a tough Monday: A jittery outlook for big banks. Grim news of potential bankruptcy filings for Ford (F) and General Motors  (GM). Health insurers buckling under tightfisted Medicaid allowances.
The result drove the Dow and S&P 500 to 12-year lows. The Nasdaq closed 70 points from a six-year low, the NYSE less than 20 points away.
Volume was well below Friday's frenetic levels. But preliminary data showed it was still above average on both exchanges.
All but one of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD lost ground during the session. The health maintenance organizations group careened more than 10% lower. Accident and health insurers skidded 9%.
The super-regional banks segment managed a less-than-1% advance, with Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) and Suntrust Banks (STI) grabbing 20% and 7% gains.

In after-hours trading, Nordstrom (JWN) rung up a 12% gain after reporting its Q4 earnings slipped 66% to 31 cents a share, but still beating estimates by a penny. The retail chain said it sees '09 earnings between $1.10 and $1.40 a share. Shares had slipped 5% during the regular session.
The Conference Board will release its Consumer Confidence data Wednesday at 10 a.m. EST. Fed chief Ben Bernanke will begin his semi-annual report to Congress Tuesday and Wednesday.

Earnings season is still in full bloom, with Astec Industries (ASTE), Ceradyne (CRDN), Macy's (M) and Home Depot (HD) among the many slated to report prior to the opening. First Solar (FSLR), Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Herbalife  (HLF) and others will report after the close.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Sink To Lowest Levels Since 1997
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The S&P 500 and Dow closed at their lowest levels since 1997 on growing unease about the financial sector.
Indexes closed at session lows as the S&P plunged 3.5%, the Dow 3.4%, the NYSE composite 3.6% and the Nasdaq 3.7%.
Volume fell, though the decline was broad. Almost every one of IBD's 197 industry groups slid.
The selling intensified late as CNBC reported that AIG (AIG) is in talks with U.S. officials about obtaining more funds to continue operating after March 2.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Hit New Lows; Energy Joins Downturn
BY ALAN R. ELLIOTT
Indexes paused, then drilled to new lows as industries from steel producers to health insurers took heavy hits.

The Nasdaq tore off a 3.1% loss. The NYSE composite, Dow and S&P 500 carved up 2.9% declines. The NYSE's energy sector took over for financials, posting the exchange's heaviest falls. Chevron (CVX) dropped 3%, and Exxon Mobil (XOM) dipped 2%.
Crude oil sat effectively flat, and gold was down only a few dollars. Natural gas added a dime as most other commodities traded mixed.

HMOs, hospitals, and accident and health insurers continued to get hammered after the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services on Friday proposed a much smaller than expected increase in rates for privately run Medicare Advantage plans for 2010.
HealthSpring (HS) tumbled 30%. Humana (HUM) caved 23%. Amerigroup (AG)P) plunged 9% in powerful action.

Lincoln Electric (LECO) slipped 9% after reporting Q4 earnings that just met analyst expectations. Revenue fell 9% to $526.2 million, far short of views for $539.6 million. The move pushed the maker of welding equipment and accessories to test support near 34. A break below that support would push it to its lowest mark since '07.
Natural gas pipeline operator Oneok Partners  (OKS) dropped 5% in heavy trade. Shares have declined in three of the past four weeks.
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Extend Losses In Afternoon Trade

5:15 p.m. Update: Mark this one down as a tough Monday: A jittery outlook for big banks. Grim news of potential bankruptcy filings for Ford (F) and General Motors  (GM). Health insurers buckling under tightfisted Medicaid allowances.The result drove the Dow and S&P 500 to 12-year lows. The Nasdaq closed 70 points from a six-year low, the NYSE less than 20 points away.Volume was well below Friday's frenetic levels. But preliminary data showed it was still above average on both exchanges.All but one of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD lost ground during the session. The health maintenance organizations group careened more than 10% lower. Accident and health insurers skidded 9%.The super-regional banks segment managed a less-than-1% advance, with Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) and Suntrust Banks (STI) grabbing 20% and 7% gains.In after-hours trading, Nordstrom (JWN) rung up a 12% gain after reporting its Q4 earnings slipped 66% to 31 cents a share, but still beating estimates by a penny. The retail chain said it sees '09 earnings between $1.10 and $1.40 a share. Shares had slipped 5% during the regular session.The Conference Board will release its Consumer Confidence data Wednesday at 10 a.m. EST. Fed chief Ben Bernanke will begin his semi-annual report to Congress Tuesday and Wednesday.Earnings season is still in full bloom, with Astec Industries (ASTE), Ceradyne (CRDN), Macy's (M) and Home Depot (HD) among the many slated to report prior to the opening.
