X Market bulls, sit tight. The bears still have not come out swinging. Wednesday's dull action was ideal for a down day for most key indexes. The Nasdaq composite and the S&P 500 finished 0.1% lower, while the NYSE composite eased 0.2%. The Russell 2000 lost nearly 0.5%, but still has some of last week's nearly 0.8% gain.…

Wearable fitness device maker Fitbit (FIT) saw its stock fall for the second day in a row after it received another round of negative analyst reports following its fourth-quarter warning.Fitbit stock ended regular trading down 0.8% to 6.01 on the stock market today. It was trading just above its all-time low of 5.90, reached Monday.Fitbit fell 16% on Monday after it preannounced dismal holiday-quarter results.The San Francisco-based company said it expects Q4 sales of $572 million to $580 million, compared with its previously announced guidance range of $725 million to $750 million. Fitbit now expects to post a loss in the December quarter of 51 to 56 cents a share minus items, compared with its previous target of a profit of 14 to 18 cents on a non-GAAP basis.IBD'S TAKE: Fitbit ranks No. 9 out of 10 stocks in IBD's Consumer Products-Electronic industry group. To see which companies lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Fitbit will report its final Q4 numbers on Feb. 22.Fitbit on Monday also drastically lowered expectations for 2017. It expects a full-year loss of 22 to 44 cents a share on revenue of $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion.Wall Street was modeling Fitbit to earn 64 cents a share ex items on sales of $2.38 billion in 2017.Citi analyst Stanley Kovler downgraded Fitbit to sell from neutral and set a price target of 5.Edison Investment Research analyst Richard Windsor grouped Fitbit with action-camera maker GoPro (GPRO) and said both stocks should be "assiduously avoided in 2017 as both have further to fall" before they become acquisition targets."Users appear to be becoming bored with fitness tracking," Windsor said in a research report Tuesday. Activity trackers like those made by Fitbit have been "a solution looking for a problem," he said.Fitbit devices have basic sensors for tracking recreational health and haven't proven to be useful enough for most consumers, Windsor said.The company claims to have 23.2 million active users, but there are many devices gathering dust in drawers, he said. Fitbit needs to innovate to avoid commoditization in the category from low-cost rivals. It needs new sensors, such as ones for measuring blood pressure or blood sugar, Windsor said.Fitbit's preannouncement "may have ruined any investor confidence that was left" in the company, Oppenheimer analyst Andrew Uerkwitz said in a report. He said his outperform rating is under review.Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy said the "most alarming" news in the report is that Fitbit is now burning cash as its free cash flow has turned negative. She rates Fitbit as underweight.With the market for fitness trackers saturated, Fitbit is trying to move into smartwatches, a category where it trails Apple (AAPL) and Garmin (GRMN)."Entry into smart/running watches obviously could help, but we question whether Fitbit's brand can pivot into these adjacent markets where allegiance is much more strongly tied to brands like Garmin, Suunto and Polar for fitness, and Apple or Samsung for smartwatches," Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brad Erickson said in a report. He rates the stock as sector weight.RELATED:Fitbit Slashes Expectations For Q4, Year Ahead; Shifts To Smartwatches

Wearable fitness device maker Fitbit (FIT) called in sick on Monday, revealing worse-than-expected fourth-quarter sales, a surprise loss and a round of layoffs to cut costs.Fitbit stock tumbled to an all-time low of 5.97 on the stock market today and only recovered a small amount of that by the closing bell. Fitbit ended trading down 16% to 6.06.The San Francisco-based company said it expects Q4 sales of $572 million to $580 million, compared with its previously announced guidance range of $725 million to $750 million.Fitbit also expects to post a loss of 51 to 56 cents a share minus items, compared with its previous target of a profit of 14 to 18 cents on a non-GAAP basis.IBD'S TAKE: Fitbit stock has a near bottom-of-the-barrel IBD Composite Rating of 7, meaning it has been outperformed by 93% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. It ranks last out of 10 stocks in IBD's Consumer Products-Electronic industry group. To see which company leads the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected Fitbit to earn 17 cents a share excluding items on sales of $736 million in Q4."Fourth-quarter results are expected to be below our prior guidance range; however, we are confident this performance is not reflective of the value of our brand, market-leading platform, and company's long-term potential," Fitbit CEO James Park said in a statement. "While we have experienced softer-than-expected holiday demand for trackers in our most mature markets, especially during Black Friday, we have continued to grow rapidly in select markets like EMEA (Europe, Middle East and Africa), where revenue grew 58% during the fourth quarter."Park called the company's Q4 results "a temporary slowdown and transition period." He said the company will be placing a greater emphasis now on smartwatches.Fitbit will report its final Q4 numbers on Feb. 22.Fitbit announced a reorganization of its business to lower operating expenses. It will cut about 110 jobs, or 6% of its global workforce."We believe the evolving wearables market continues to present growth opportunities for us that we will capitalize on by investing in our core product offerings, while expanding into the smartwatch category to diversify revenue and capture share of the over $10 billion global smartwatch market," Park said. "We are uniquely positioned to succeed in delivering what consumers are looking for in a smartwatch: stylish, well-designed devices that combine the right general purpose functionality with a focus on health and fitness. With the recent acquisition of assets from Pebble, Vector Watch and Coin, we are taking action to position the company for long-term success."Fitbit is the leader in basic activity trackers, but has been losing ground to smartwatches with fitness features such as those from Apple (AAPL) and Garmin (GRMN).Fitbit said the first half of 2017 will be challenging and face difficult year-over-year comparisons. Fitbit expects "stabilization in financial performance in the second half of 2017."For 2017, it guided to revenue of $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion. It expects a loss of 22 to 44 cents a share.Wall Street was modeling Fitbit to earn 64 cents a share ex items on sales of $2.38 billion in 2017.Fitbit bear Trip Chowdhry, an analyst with Global Equities Research, issued a report Monday where he basically said, "I told you so.""Right from the IPO of FIT (Fitbit), GER research has been indicating FIT is a total junk," Chowdhry said.Fitbit went public in June 2015 at 20 and climbed as high as 51.90 in August 2015 before starting its descent.CFRA Research analyst Angelo Zino cut his price target on Fitbit stock to 8 from 11. "We expect high channel inventory and intense competition to pressure margins," Zino said in a research note early Monday. "We see limited visibility on new product offerings."FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi cut his price target to 9 from 15.Mizuho Securities analyst Betty Chen kept her neutral rating on Fitbit stock, but slashed her price target to 6.50 from 9. Fitbit is facing "slowing category growth, potential domestic saturation, and weak adoption abroad," she said in a report Monday.RELATED:CES: Fitbit Getting Users Active With Incentives, Games

Navigation products maker Garmin (GRMN) was at one time a darling of the growth-stock camp. In 2006, the stock rose 68% and then followed with a gain of 74% in 2007. Earnings jumped 64% and 62% those two years, and revenue climbed 73% and 79%. Growth investors were happy. But in 2008, the stock dived 80%. Fast growth, especially on…

Shares of graphics chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) whipsawed on Thursday as investors reacted to technical sell signals and a bullish report from Goldman Sachs.Nvidia stock fell as much as 5.9% in morning trading before reversing, rising 2% to 111.43 on the stock market today. Nvidia continued to trade heavily after the closing bell, rising about 1%.On Wednesday, Nvidia tumbled 6.9% to 109.25 in heavy trading, its biggest decline of the year.Investment bank Goldman Sachs on Thursday issued a positive report on Nvidia, noting that the company has upcoming catalysts, the early January CES trade show and its Q4 earnings report in February.In its Weekly Options Watch report, Goldman said it sees opportunities to play Nvidia and Garmin (GRMN) ahead of the annual consumer electronics show, which officially begins Jan. 5 in Las Vegas.IBD'S TAKE: Nvidia stock is ranked No. 1 on the IBD 50 list of top growth stocks, thanks to its stellar performance in 2016. But it flashed technical sell signals as it reached a record high Tuesday. Read the article "How Far Will Nvidia Correct In Price?""This event is a popular venue for companies to announce new technology and even update investors on current financials," Goldman Sachs analysts said in its research report. "However, we find the options market is not pricing in this historically stock moving event."Goldman recommended that investors buy Nvidia March calls ahead of CES and the company's February financial report."Nvidia's CEO will be making the opening keynote address at CES 2017 and the company will be unveiling new products in AI, self-driving cars and gaming," Goldman said.During the last five CES shows, Nvidia shares have risen an average of 4% during the four-day event, the bank said.Goldman analyst Toshiya Hari views Nvidia "as a unique growth story in semis, levered to positive secular trends in gaming, VR (virtual reality), AI (artificial intelligence), ML (machine learning) and automotive."Meanwhile, Goldman was negative on GPS and wearable device maker Garmin, citing competitive risks."Our analyst sees risks that demand for the company's wearable products will underwhelm this holiday season, in particular as competitors launch new products," the analysts said.Goldman recommended buying Garmin February puts ahead of CES.At CES 2016, shares of Garmin rival Fitbit (FIT) were pummeled after the company introduced the Fitbit Blaze smart fitness watch, which many observers said compared poorly to Apple's (AAPL) Apple Watch smartwatch.Goldman analyst Simona Jankowski sees signs that Garmin wearables sales during the holiday shopping season were weak vs. new products from Fitbit and Apple's second-generation Apple Watch.Garmin stock slipped 0.4% Thursday to 49.01, down 13% from a 22-month high of 56.19 touched on Aug. 1. RELATED:Down Comes Nvidia And The Tech ETFs That Rode It To Stellar GainsNvidia Flashes Key Sell Signal Amid Citron Tweet, Possible Climax RunCES 2017: News From The World's Largest Consumer Tech Show

Fitbit (FIT) stock surged on Tuesday after software apps associated with its wearable fitness devices jumped to among the top downloads on the Apple (AAPL) and Google app stores following Christmas.Investors interpreted the app download activity as a positive sign for Fitbit device sales over the holiday season.Fitbit jumped as much as 9.3% on the news Tuesday, ending at 7.84, up 7.5%, on the stock market today.Fitbit stock hit an all-time low of 7.20 on Friday.IBD'S TAKE: Fitbit stock has a near bottom-of-the-barrel IBD Composite Rating of 5, meaning it has been outperformed by 95% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. It ranks No. 8 out of 10 stocks in IBD's Consumer Products-Electronic industry group. To see which company leads the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.CFRA Research analyst Scott Kessler reiterated his hold rating on Fitbit on the news.The flurry of app download activity is indicative of "considerable holiday gift purchases" of Fitbit devices, he said in a research note.However, Fitbit was not mentioned by Amazon.com (AMZN) in its press release highlighting the best-selling wearable technology products on the e-commerce site. Instead, Amazon pointed to strong sales of a fitness band and smartwatch from rival Garmin (GRMN).Other top-selling tech products on Amazon.com over the holiday season included Amazon's own Echo smart speakers, Samsung TVs, and Nintendo (NTDOY) "Pokemon Sun and Moon" video games.Meanwhile, action camera maker GoPro (GPRO) received some coal in its stocking from Piper Jaffray on Tuesday.Piper analyst Erinn Murphy reiterated her underweight rating on GoPro stock after signs of a disappointing holiday sales period. She lowered her sales estimates for GoPro for Q4 and beyond."Our weekly Amazon tracking indicates the average pricing basket of GoPro products has seen a sequential quarterly decline from $282 in Q3 to $265 in Q4," she said in a report. The GoPro pricing basket is down 9% from Q4 last year when it was $292, she said.Retailers were using promotional pricing to move GoPro products, including its new Hero 5 cameras, Murphy said.GoPro stock fell 1.1% to 9.09 on Tuesday.RELATED:The Top Selling Products On Amazon Over Holidays Came From ... AmazonFitbit Buys Pebble Smartwatch Assets

Shares of Fitbit (FIT) fell to a record low on Thursday after Deutsche Bank downgraded the stock to hold from buy on signs of slowing sales of wearable fitness trackers.Fitbit shares dropped as low as 7.76 intraday, its lowest price since going public at 20 in June 2015. Fitbit ended the regular session down 0.6% to 7.92 on the stock market today.Deutsche Bank analyst Sherri Scribner lowered her rating on the stock and slashed her price target to 9 from 18."We continue to view Fitbit as a leader in the wearable fitness category, but given consumer demand appears to be waning for wearable devices, we are taking a wait-and-see approach to the name," she said in a report Wednesday.She cited recent data from research firm IDC, which indicated that sales of wearables grew just 3% in the third quarter, a significant deceleration from growth of 67% and 26% in Q1 and Q2, respectively.IBD'S TAKE: Fitbit stock has a lowly IBD Composite Rating of 6, meaning it has been outperformed by 94% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. More attractive stocks for investors to consider can be found on the IBD 50 list of top growth companies."Demand for wearable devices may be experiencing a pause, as consumers with interest in wearables have likely already purchased a device, and new consumers are not yet compelled to buy yet another device," she said. "We believe new features are necessary to drive further adoption into the mass market."Fitbit's purchase Wednesday of software assets and engineering talent from smartwatch startup Pebble adds some interesting intellectual property but isn't material to results, Scribner said. Fitbit had a small and declining share of the smartwatch market, she said.Fitbit did not buy Pebble's hardware business. Pebble is shutting down and liquidating its current inventory of smartwatches.Fitbit shares have been hit by slowing demand for activity trackers, competition from smartwatches, and concerns that wearable fitness devices might be a fad. Fitbit competes with low-cost activity trackers from vendors like China's Xiaomi, smartwatches from Apple (AAPL) and Samsung, and sports watches from Garmin (GRMN).RELATED:Apple Watch Q3 Shipments Plunge; Fitbit Lead Widens In WearablesApple CEO Tim Cook: Trust Me, Apple Watch Sales Are Hot

The holidays were happy ones for Amazon.com (AMZN), which says that its very own hardware products, led by the Echo Dot, were its best-selling products.Following the Echo Dot, Amazon said the best-selling products over the holiday season overall were the Fire TV Stick, the Fire Tablet and the Amazon Echo.Amazon says it has sold "millions" of the Echo Dot since its introduction. The Echo Dot, which costs $49.99, is the low-end version of the Amazon Echo, which sells for $179.99. The Echo, including Dot, is a voice activated, Wi-Fi-connected smart speaker linked to the cloud. With the voice of the artificially intelligent Alexa, Echo serves up music, news, traffic and weather, plays games, answers questions and does much more.Amazon stock was up 1.5% near 772 in afternoon trading in the stock market today, just below its 50-day moving average.The Amazon Echo, a similar device by the Google unit of Alphabet (GOOGL) and another being developed by Microsoft (MSFT) are expected to play a key role in the smart home. Alphabet recently followed Amazon with the introduction of Google Home, which sells for $129. Google Home is a voice-activated speaker powered by Google Allo, its artificially intelligent assistant.IBD'S TAKE: The battle to provide the best digital butler for homes is one that Amazon and other tech leaders will be fighting for years. These in-home devices with artificial intelligence and language processing skills could evolve into the next major disruption in computing and put the smart home on a fast track.Microsoft has yet to introduce a similar device for the home, but it has deep roots in artificial intelligence with its Cortana platform, available on mobile devices and PCs. This is also true of Apple with its Siri platform and Facebook (FB) with its Messenger platform.Microsoft last week gave a sneak peak at a new hardware device that looks similar to Echo. The device has the Harman (HAR) label but is voice-controlled through Cortana.Among other top-selling products on Amazon over the holiday sales period were memory cards from Western Digital (WDC)-owned SanDisk, wearable technology from Garmin (GRMN), Samsung TVs, Levi's and Spalding basketballs.Online shoppers swarmed to Amazon this holiday season. The the e-commerce leader has gained share vs. Best Buy (BBY), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Apple (AAPL).Amazon said more than 72% of Amazon customers worldwide shopped using a mobile device this holiday.RELATED:Amazon Introduces 'Amazon Go' Retail Stores, No Checkout, No LinesAmazon Set To Disrupt Retailers In Apparel, Groceries, ServicesApple, Microsoft, Alphabet Are Kings Of Cash As Tech Sector Rules

Apple Watch sales to consumers hit record levels in the first week of holiday shopping, Apple (AAPL) CEO Tim Cook told Reuters, countering new data that said the tech titan's wearables sales have crashed.Cook said Apple Watch sell-through rate, which measures how many units are actually sold to consumers vs. on sent to retailers, rose to a record level. But Cook didn't offer any specific figures.Responding to a Reuters email, Cook said the gadget's sell-through — a measure of how many units are sold to consumers, rather than simply stocked on retailers' shelves — reached a new high."Sales growth is off the charts. In fact, during the first week of holiday shopping, our sell-through of Apple Watch was greater than any week in the product's history," Cook told Reuters.Cook's response followed a Monday IDC report that Apple Watch shipments fell 71% in Q3 vs. a year earlier, even as wearables overall rose 3.1%. Fitness tracker Fitbit (FIT) expanded its lead as No. 1 in wearables, while No. 5 Samsung showed the strongest growth. China's Xiaomi and Garmin (GRMN) are No. 2 and No. 3 in wearables.Apple sales likely plunged in part as consumers awaited the Apple Watch 2. Cook's claimed holiday sales spike supports that argument. That doesn't necessarily ease concerns about the long-term future for the Apple Watch or smartwatches generally.Shares of Apple rose 0.7% to 109.92 just before the closing bell on the stock market today. The stock fell 0.7% to 109.10 on Monday, continuing to trade below its 50-day moving average.Fitbit, which recently reported weak quarterly results and a grim holiday forecast, fell 0.5% to 7.99 intraday. Fitbit lost 1.4% to 8.03 on Monday.Garmin stock fell 1.2% to 51.52 after climbing 1.2% on Monday. Shares have a potential buy point at 56.29, after the stock touched a 19-month high of 56.19 on Aug. 1.RELATED:Apple Confirms Self-Driving Car Interest, 'Investing Heavily' In Automation

Despite a 71% plunge in shipments of Apple's (AAPL) Apple Watch devices, overall shipments of wearables rose 3.1% in the third quarter vs. the year-earlier quarter, market tracker IDC said Monday.Fitbit (FIT) widened its lead, according to IDC's numbers, but among the top five vendors Samsung had the biggest rise."It's still early days, but we're already seeing a notable shift in the market," IDC analyst Jitesh Ubrani said in the company's release. "Where smartwatches were once expected to take the lead, basic wearables now reign supreme."Simplicity is a driving factor and this is well reflected in the top vendor list as four out of five (all but Apple) offer a simple, dedicated fitness device. Meanwhile, from a design perspective, many devices are focusing on fashion first while allowing the technology to blend in with the background."IBD'S TAKE: Wearables aren't a hot sector, but there always are some fields doing well. And to find them, IBD's Industry Snapshot is one place to regularly check.IDC said fitness bands and basic wearables accounted for 85% of the market and jumped by double digits.Total shipments rose to 23 million from 22.3 million in Q3 2015, the firm said. The wearables rise outpaced smartphones, which saw just a 1% rise in Q3 shipments, IDC said in October.For Q3, Apple Watch shipments skidded to 1.1 million, IDC said, hurt by the late-quarter release (mid-September) of its second-generation watches. IDC also criticized what it called the Apple Watch's "unintuitive user interface." It says that problem's been addressed with the new Watch, but said "Apple's success will likely be muted as the smartwatch category continues to be challenged."Fitbit saw an 11% rise in Q3 shipments, to 5.3 million, with its market share rising to 23% from 21.4%. China's Xiaomi is No. 2, but despite a 4% Q3 rise, its overall share barely rose to 16.5% from 16.4%.No. 3 Garmin (GRMN) had a 12.2% Q3 increase, with its market share up to 5.7% from 5.3%.Next comes Apple, though its market share tumbled to just 4.9%, from 17.5% in Q3 2015.No. 5 Samsung saw its shipments nearly double to 1 million, and its share rose to 4.5% from 2.5%. The other vendors combined recorded a 26.1% rise in Q3 shipments, as the market fragmented."Smart wearables have been down in recent quarters, but clearly not out," IDC analyst Ramon Llamas said in the release. "As user tastes change, so will their needs. That's the opportunity for smart wearables with multi-functionality and third-party applications, both for consumers and business users."Garmin stock ended trading up more than 1% on the stock market today, to close at 52.13. Shares have a possible buy point at 56.29, after the stock touched a 19-month high of 56.19 on Aug. 1. Shares of Apple were down 0.7% to 109.10 while Fitbit lost 1.4% to 8.03.RELATED:Apple Price Target Cut As iPhone 7 Momentum SlowsApple Confirms Interest In Self-Driving CarsFitbit Reportedly Will Buy Wearables Maker Pebble

Fitness tracker Fitbit (FIT), which faces the Apple Watch and other challenges, will buy struggling smartwatch maker Pebble, according to various reports.Fitbit wants Pebble's intellectual property and software, and will shut down the company and its products over time, The Information said, citing sources.The Information, which gave the initial report late Wednesday, didn't specify the price, but TechCrunch reported it would be $34 million-$40 million, well below the $740 million that Pebble reportedly turned down from watchmaker Citizen in 2015.Pebble was one of the first wearable makers, getting funding via Kickstarter, and it has largely stuck to its simple design and no-touch functionality.Pebble launched its latest model, Pebble 2, in October after reportedly laying off one-quarter of its staff earlier in the year.IBD'S TAKE: Smartwatches are the only gadgets short-circuiting with consumers. Action camera maker GoPro gave a weak holiday outlook and days later recalled its just-launched Karma drone.Fitbit also has been struggling, reporting a deeper-than-expected earnings decline and a weak holiday outlook on Nov. 2. Fitbit shares crashed 34% the next day to an all-time low.Fitbit shares haven't recovered much since then. Shares ended trading up 0.7% to 8.42 on the stock market today.The Apple Watch, including the all-new Apple Watch 2, could be one problem for Fitbit. Samsung, Lenovo, Garmin (GRMN) and many others have entered the market. Alphabet (GOOGL)-unit Google will release two smartwatches in Q1 and has its Android Wear software.But there are also signs that smartwatch sales have waned as initial interest tapers off, though the shipment drop may reflect product cycles.

Wearable fitness device maker Fitbit (FIT) earned a cautious upgrade from Pacific Crest Securities on Wednesday based on its low valuation.Pacific Crest analyst Brad Erickson raised his rating on Fitbit to sector weight, or neutral, from underweight, or sell. He continues to view fair value for Fitbit stock around 8. Fitbit fell 1% to 9.46 on the stock market today."While our views of maturity for wearables driving headwinds to growth remain, the stock now more fully reflects the skepticism we expressed in our Sept. 29 downgrade to underweight," Erickson said in his research report. "Fitbit faces increasingly stiffening headwinds to growth, driven by a lack of utility and poor user trends."IBD'S TAKE: Fitbit stock has a lowly IBD Composite Rating of 9, meaning it has been outperformed by 91% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For a list of better investment opportunities, check out the IBD 50 list of superior stocks.For Fitbit to regain its footing, it will need to show continued consumer demand for its devices and traction for corporate health care initiatives, Erickson said.He expects Fitbit unit sales growth to decelerate to the high single-digits in 2016 and then decline by 6.7% in 2017."We think fitness trackers are hitting saturation in developed markets, with opportunities in emerging geographies appearing much more limited, at least for Fitbit-like price points," Erickson said.Fitbit needs to compete more with Garmin (GRMN) and others in the sports watch category, Erickson said."The main opportunity where Fitbit could improve meaningfully in 2017 is in running watches," he said. "Fitbit needs to crack into the specialty channel, not to necessarily drive volume, but to drive consumer street credit as more than a tracker."Fitbit shares tumbled after the San Francisco-based company on Nov. 2 posted disappointing third-quarter results and badly missed Wall Street's targets for the December quarter.On Wednesday, video game publisher Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) announced that it has partnered with Fitbit to give players of "NBA 2K17" in-game rewards for healthy activity tracked by Fitbit devices.Players who achieve 10,000 steps in a day tracked with their Fitbit device will receive a temporary attribute boost to their MyPlayer in "NBA 2K17," enhancing their in-game performance on the court.It's not the first tie-up between a wearables maker and a video game company.In September, Apple (AAPL) announced that it would bring "Pokemon Go" to the Apple Watch. The popular augmented reality game from Niantic has encouraged players to be more active by going for walks to look for and hatch digital creatures in the game.RELATED:Wireless Headphones, 4K TVs, Drones Top Christmas Wish ListsTake-Two Jumps To New High On Slam-Dunk Q2 Earnings

Fitbit (FIT) stock on Thursday fell to an all-time low, after the maker of wearable fitness trackers offered a weak sales outlook for the holiday shopping season.Fitbit shares fell 33.6% to 8.51 on the stock market today. Fitbit made its IPO in June 2015 at 20 and climbed as high as 51.90 in August 2015 before gravity took hold.San Francisco-based Fitbit late Wednesday posted disappointing third-quarter results and badly missed Wall Street's targets for the December quarter.Fitbit earned 11 cents a share in Q3, down 42% year over year and missing Wall Street's estimate by a penny. Sales rose 23% to $503.8 million, but missed the consensus view of $506.9 million.Excluding items like stock-based compensation, Fitbit earned 19 cents a share, down 21% but in line with Wall Street's consensus target.IBD'S TAKE: Fitbit stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 10, meaning it has been outperformed by 90% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. Investors looking for leading stocks to add to their watch lists should check out the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.For the current quarter, Fitbit expects to earn 16 cents a share excluding items on sales of $737.5 million, based on the midpoint of its guidance. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were modeling Fitbit to earn 75 cents a share on sales of $985.1 million.Fitbit's Q4 sales outlook targets 3% to 4% year-over-year growth for the Christmas shopping period. The company's year-over-year sales growth has decelerated for six straight quarters, from 253% growth in Q2 2015 to 23% growth last quarter. The trend has investors questioning demand for fitness wearables, especially activity trackers where Fitbit reigns.Fitbit is facing increasing competition from smartwatches with health and fitness features, such as Apple's (AAPL) Apple Watch, and sports watches from Garmin (GRMN). Fitbit continues to lead in the market for basic fitness wearables, but analysts say that market is being cannibalized by smartwatches. Fitbit responded to the smartwatch threat by releasing its Blaze smart fitness watch in March.Fitbit's downbeat report led to a wave of downgrades and price-target cuts on the stock.Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy downgraded Fitbit stock to underweight from neutral. She also cut her price target on Fitbit to 8 from 14."While we have been on the sidelines since February, wary on the second-half nature of the year, we did not anticipate a guide-down of this magnitude this early on in the holiday" season, she said in a research report. "We now find ourselves struggling to model out a scenario where units — which are now implied to be flat to down year-over-year in Q4 — can re-accelerate in first-half 2017."Plus, ongoing competition from Apple, Fossil (FOSL), Xiaomi and others could further pressure Fitbit's average selling prices, Murphy said.Oppenheimer analyst Andrew Uerkwitz called Fitbit "completely out of shape." He slashed his price target on the stock to 12 from 25, but maintained his outperform rating.For the stock to work, the company needs to show signs that it can leverage its vast amount of data, corporate relationships and social network, Uerkwitz said in a report.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brad Erickson reiterated his underweight rating on Fitbit stock. He has a price target of 8 on the stock, with a bear case of 6."Our Q4 fears of market maturity were confirmed with Fitbit's disastrous Q4 guidance," Erickson said in a report. "New products in 2017 will determine the future of the company."Morgan Stanley analyst Jerry Liu lowered his rating on Fitbit stock to equal weight from overweight and slashed his price target to 11 from 31."Fitbit needs new products and partnerships to re-accelerate growth," Liu said in a report. "The company said it needs to add more features and functionality to its hardware and software, and refine the marketing message to customers across different regions in order to drive higher demand going forward."Cowen analyst John Kernan lowered his price target on Fitbit to 9 from 18 and stuck with his market perform rating.RELATED:Apple Tanks, Garmin Gains In Q3 Smartwatch MarketFossil Targets Apple Watch With New Smartwatch Lineup

Wearable fitness device maker Fitbit (FIT) late Wednesday posted disappointing Q3 results and forecast a poor holiday selling period.Fitbit stock cratered in after-hours trading, falling 30% after the earnings report. During the regular session Wednesday, Fitbit shares dipped 1.9% to 12.81.San Francisco-based Fitbit earned 19 cents a share excluding items, down 21% year over year but in line with Wall Street's consensus target, in the quarter ended Oct. 1. Sales rose 23% to $503.8 million, but missed the consensus view of $506.9 million.Under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), Fitbit earned 11 cents a share, down 42% and missing Wall Street's estimate by a penny.For the December quarter, Fitbit forecast non-GAAP earnings per share of 14 to 18 cents, or 16 cents at the midpoint. It expects revenue of $725 million to $750 million, representing growth of 2% to 5%. Wall Street was modeling Fitbit to earn 75 cents a share on sales of $985.1 million.IBD'S TAKE: Fitbit stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 13, meaning it has been outperformed by 87% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. Investors looking for leading stocks to add to their watch lists should read the article, "Stocks Near A Buy Zone: Activision In Buy Range Ahead Of Q3 Earnings."Fitbit is facing increasing competition from smartwatches with health and fitness features, such as Apple's (AAPL) Apple Watch Series 2, and sports watches from Garmin (GRMN). Fitbit continues to lead in the market for basic fitness wearables, but analysts say that market is being cannibalized by smartwatches. Fitbit responded to the smartwatch threat by releasing its Blaze smart fitness watch in March."We continue to grow and are profitable, however not at the pace previously expected," Fitbit CEO James Park said in a statement. "We are focused on improving the utility of our products and integrating more deeply into the healthcare ecosystem and believe we can leverage our brand and community to unlock new avenues and adjacencies of growth."Fitbit's year-over-year sales growth has decelerated for six straight quarters, from 253% growth in Q2 2015 to 23% growth last quarter.Single-digit sales growth forecast for the holiday season is raising doubts about the health of the market for fitness wearables, especially activity trackers where Fitbit reigns.Fitbit sold 5.3 million devices in Q3, compared with 4.8 million in the year-earlier period, an increase of 10%.Fitbit said 60% of its product activations last quarter came from new customers, while 40% were from repeat customers.New products – Fitbit Blaze, Alta, Charge 2, Flex 2 and related accessories – comprised 79% of Q3 revenue, compared with 54% in Q2, Fitbit said.RELATED:Microsoft Quits Fitness Band Business; Move Could Benefit FitbitFitbit Gaining Share, But Earnings Estimates Look Lofty For 2017Fitbit Downgraded On Charge 2 Reception, Apple Watch Win

Apple (AAPL) once again released quarterly financial results without disclosing how many smartwatches it sold in the period.The Cupertino, Calif.-based consumer electronics giant details how many iPhones, iPads and Mac computers it sells, but not the Apple Watch. It combines Apple Watch results in its catch-all "Other Products" category, which also includes iPod, Apple TV, Beats headphones and other accessories.Apple late Tuesday said revenue in its Other Products category fell 22% year over year to $2.73 billion in its fiscal fourth quarter ended Sept. 24. The period included just nine days of sales of Apple's second-generation smartwatch, the Apple Watch Series 2, which came out on Sept. 16.Wall Street analysts parsed the data and tried to determine how many watches Apple sold in its September quarter. Based on 10 analysts who estimated Apple Watch sales, the consensus is that Apple sold 2 million units in fiscal Q4.IBD'S TAKE: Apple stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 78, meaning it has outperformed 78% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. But IBD believes there are stocks with greater potential for big gains for investors to consider. IBD's Leaderboard features a select group of such stocks.Baird was the outlier on the high side, estimating that Apple sold 2.9 million watches last quarter. Deutsche Bank and UBS had the lowest estimates at 1.1 million units.On Monday, research firm IDC estimated that Apple shipped 1.1 million smartwatches in the calendar third quarter. IDC tracks shipments, not sales, and had one more week in its figures than Apple's fiscal Q4.The IDC report had Apple in first place for smartwatch shipments with 41.3% market share, followed by Garmin (GRMN) (20.5%), Samsung (14.4%) and Lenovo (3.4%).In July, after Apple announced June quarter earnings, the consensus on Wall Street was that Apple would sell 2.4 million smartwatches in the September quarter.At least eight analysts made estimates for Apple Watch sales in the December quarter. The consensus among those analysts is that Apple will sell 4.7 million smartwatches in the holiday sales quarter.Apple stock fell 2.3% Wednesday on its mixed fiscal Q4 results.On a conference call with analysts Tuesday, Apple CEO Tim Cook said he is happy with sales of the Apple Watch Series 2 so far."We're also off to a great start with Apple Watch Series 2, the next generation of the world's most popular smartwatch, packed with new features including built-in GPS, water resistance, a dramatically brighter display and a powerful dual-core processor," Cook said. "Individuals and businesses alike are recognizing the potential of Apple Watch to help people stay healthy, motivated and connected."RELATED:5 Takeaways From Apple's Mixed Q4 Earnings ReportLower-Priced Apple Watch 1 Might Outsell New Apple Watch 2 This Holiday

The Apple Watch held on to the lead in the smartwatch market in the third quarter, but its shipments tumbled. Meanwhile, Garmin (GRMN) jumped from fifth place to No. 2 in smartwatch market share, research firm IDC reported Monday.Apple (AAPL) shipped 1.1 million smartwatches in the September quarter, down 72% from the 3.9 million it shipped in Q3 2015. It still took first place in the market with a 41.3% share, but that was down from 70.2% a year earlier, IDC said.IBD'S TAKE: Apple stock performance is tied largely to its iPhone business, which is facing headwinds in a maturing market. Apple stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 68, meaning it has outperformed 68% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more information on Apple, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Apple could see a rebound this quarter thanks to the launch of its second-generation Apple Watch and lower pricing for the first-generation Apple Watch, IDC said. Apple started selling its Apple Watch Series 2 on Sept. 16.The Apple Watch also could see a lift from its deal with health insurer Aetna. Aetna announced Sept. 27 that it will subsidize the cost of the Apple Watch to select large employers and individual customers. Aetna also will provide Apple Watch at no cost to its nearly 50,000 employees, who will participate in the company's wellness reimbursement program.Meanwhile, Garmin posted a big increase in smartwatch shipments in Q3, thanks to its growing list of ConnectIQ-enabled smartwatches and the addition of the Fenix Chronos. Garmin's smartwatches focus on health and fitness, while other vendors make multipurpose devices, IDC said.Garmin grabbed second place with 20.5% market share in the third quarter, up from 2.3% a year ago. It shipped 600,000 smartwatches in Q3, up 324% year over year.Samsung slipped from second to third place in Q3. It shipped 400,000 smartwatches last quarter, up 9%, and claimed 14.4% market share.No. 4 Lenovo had 3.4% market share, followed by Pebble with 3.2%, IDC said.Total smartwatch shipments fell 52% to 2.7 million units worldwide in Q3, IDC said."The sharp decline in smartwatch shipment volumes reflects the way platforms and vendors are realigning," IDC analyst Ramon Llamas said in a statement. "Apple revealed a new look and feel to watchOS that did not arrive until the launch of the second-generation watch at the end of September."Google's decision to hold back Android Wear 2.0 has repercussions for its (hardware) partners as to whether to launch devices before or after the holidays. Samsung's Gear S3, announced at IFA in September, has yet to be released. Collectively, this left vendors relying on older, aging devices to satisfy customers."Google is a unit of Alphabet (GOOGL).Apple stock rose 0.9%, to 117.65, in the stock market today, while Garmin shares rose a fraction, to 48.88.RELATED:Apple Analysts Place Final Bets Before Earnings Window ClosesLower-Priced Apple Watch 1 Might Outsell New Apple Watch 2 This HolidayHow Many Watches Did Apple Sell Last Quarter?

Higher-ups from Netflix (NFLX), Tesla (TSLA), Boeing (BA), Nike (NKE), Fitbit (FIT) and Gigamon (GIMO) were among those who made notable insider trades disclosed this week.Directors Timothy Haley and Richard Barton sold 23,728 shares and 2,800 shares, respectively, this week. Chief Financial Officer David Wells sold 500 shares.The Internet TV service last month reported third-quarter subscriber gains that far exceeded Street expectations, helped by such shows as "Stranger Things." The results revived its stock, for now, and eased investor concerns about the company's ability to attract new viewers. However, questions remained about its spending on new programming.Shares dropped 3.6% in the stock market this week.Director Kimbal Musk, Chief Executive Elon Musk's brother, has sold 2,779 shares of the electric auto maker.The company said this week that its intended acquisition of SolarCity (SCTY) will reap upward of $150 million in savings within the first full year after the deal's closing. Tesla has faced concerns that such a merger is essentially a bailout for the maker of solar-power systems.Shares lost 4.7% this week.CEO Mark Parker this week sold 150,000 shares of the athletic apparel maker for a value of $7.5 million.The company in September reported first-quarter results that beat expectations, despite softer-than-anticipated future  orders and the sense that the threat from rivals like Under Armour (UA) and Adidas is growing.Shares fell 4% this week.CEO Dennis Muilenburg sold 51,024 shares of the aerospace giant this week, while CFO Greg Smith sold 20,000 shares.Boeing last week said that it may debut a new midsize jet and a longer 737 Max in attempt to compete more aggressively with Airbus (EADSY).Boeing slipped 2.4% this week; Airbus gave back more than 4.7%.Director Jon Callaghan sold 15,000 shares this week. Shares of the maker of fitness-tracking devices plunged this week after its holiday-quarter forecast fell far short of expectations. The company faces pressure from Apple (AAPL) and Garmin (GRMN), which also offer wearable technology.Shares plummeted by more than 35%, with most of that drop coming on Thursday.CEO Paul Hooper this week sold 45,000 company shares. The network-traffic analytics company last week reported third-quarter results that topped views.Shares ended Friday down 1.8% for the week.RELATED:5 Takeaways From Netflix Earnings Surprise, Stock Surge

Facebook (FB), Qualcomm (QCOM), Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) and Parsley Energy (PE) topped forecasts late Wednesday, while Fitbit (FIT) shares collapsed on disastrous guidance Continental Resources (CLR) ramped up its drilling and fracking plans.Estimates: Adjusted Q3 EPS up 70% to 97 cents, ending four straight quarters of accelerating growth. Revenue up 54% to $6.92 billion.Results: EPS of $1.09 on revenue of $7.01 billion. Monthly active users rose 16% to 1.79 billion. Mobile monthly active users climbed 20% to 1.66 billion. Mobile ad revenue was 84% of the total, up from 78%.Stock: Shares were up 0.4% late after closing down 1.8% to 127.17 on the stock market today, below their 50-day average for the first time since July. The stock has been unable to get back above a 132.08 buy point in recent sessions and on Tuesday undercut an earlier entry point of 128.43 from a prior consolidation.The world's largest social network is grabbing a bigger share of online and total ad dollars while also expanding further into e-commerce.Estimates: Q3 EPS down 21% to 19 cents, with sales up 24% to $506.93 million.Results: EPS of 19 cents on revenue of $503.8 million.Outlook: Q4 EPS of 14-18 cents, vs. consensus of 75 cents, on revenue of $725 million-$750 million, below views for $985 million.Stock: Shares sank 30% after hours. Since plunging from its August 2015 peak to its June 2016 low, the stock has remained below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Fitbit's results and outlook will provide clues into the wearables market ahead of the holiday season as competition heats up vs. the Apple (AAPL) Watch and wearables from Garmin (GRMN) and others.Estimates: Fiscal Q4 EPS up 24% to $1.13; revenue up 1% to $5.842 billion.Results: Adjusted EPS of $1.28 on revenue of $6.18 billion.Outlook: Q1 EPS of $1.12-$1.22, largely below views of $1.22, on revenue of $5.7 billion-$6.5 billion, in line with consensus for $6.15 billion.Stock: Shares edged down 0.1% late.The outlook may give some indication of the fallout from Samsung's Note 7 fiasco, as well as the strength of demand for the Apple iPhone 7. Qualcomm last week announced plans to buy NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) for $39 billion.Estimates: Q3 per-share loss to widen to 15 cents from 12 cents, as revenue falls 11.4% to $556.7 million.Results: Per-share loss of 30 cents on revenue of $526.2 million.Outlook: Full-year production now seen at 215,000-220,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, an increase of 5,000 from the low end of previous guidance given in August.Continental plans to increase its gross operated well completions this year by 32, and plans to increase stimulation crews in North Dakota to four from two by the end of the year.Stock: Shares dropped 4% late after finishing down 4% as a surge in U.S. crude stockpiles sent futures lower.Estimates: Q3 to swing to a profit of 2 cents a share from a loss of 8 cents a share, with revenue more than doubling to $129.2 million.Results: Adjusted EPS of 3 cents on revenue of $132.7 million. Net production nearly doubled to 43,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day.Outlook: Full-year production now seen at 37,000-39,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up from 36,000-38,000 BOE. Parsley is adding 450 net horizontal drilling locations to its Midland Basin inventory.Stock: Shares fell 2%, dropping further below their 50-day average.The Permian Basin-focused producer is in the middle of the hottest U.S. shale formation, where oil can be extracted profitably even at lower prices.Estimates: Fiscal Q2 EPS down 3.3% to 29 cents as revenue climbs 10% to $402.6 million.Results: EPS of 45 cents on revenue of $420.2 million on bookings of $452.8 million.Outlook: Q3 EPS of 30-40 cents, below views for $1.04, on revenue of $475 million-$525 million, also below consensus for $649.7 million. Take-Two sees Q3 bookings of $650 million-$700 million.Stock: Shares jumped 4.6% in extended trade.The video game publisher follows Electronic Arts' (EA) strong results Tuesday and comes ahead of Activision Blizzard's (ATVI) report Thursday.

Like a discarded activity tracker, Microsoft (MSFT) is putting its fitness band business in the junk drawer.The software giant has pulled its Microsoft Band from its online store and has no plans for a new model any time soon, if ever, ZDnet reported Monday. The company told ZDnet it has sold through its existing Band 2 inventory.Microsoft's retreat from the fitness band market comes as rumors swirl about the future of Jawbone, another maker of wearable activity trackers. Jawbone has sold out of its Up fitness bands and is struggling financially, according to media reports.Microsoft entered the fitness band market in October 2014 and released a second-generation Microsoft Band a year later. The Band 2 costs $250 and tracks heart rate, exercise, calorie burn and sleep quality, and can provide email, text and calendar alerts by linking to a smartphone.Analysts have been predicting a winnowing out of competitors in the fitness band market. Fitbit (FIT) leads the market, but rivals include Garmin (GRMN) and Fossil Group (FOSL)-owned Misfit. Those companies also compete with makers of smartwatches that have fitness features, such as Apple's (AAPL) Apple Watch.IBD'S TAKE: Fitbit ranks No. 9 out of 11 companies in IBD's Consumer Products-Electronic industry group. To see which company leads the sector, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.On Monday, Cowen analyst John Kernan cut his price target on Fitbit stock to 18 from 20 and maintained his market perform rating. He says Fitbit's profit margins will be pressured by the company's stepped-up sales and marketing efforts next year.Fitbit stock ended 0.4% lower at 14.72 on the stock market today. Fitbit could be forming a cup-with-handle base, with a possible buy point at 17.28, but shares are down more than 40% this year. Microsoft stock dipped 0.3% to 57.24 Tuesday.RELATED:Fitbit Downgraded On Charge 2 Reception, Apple Watch Win

Consumer adoption of wearable fitness trackers continues to rise and Fitbit (FIT) is well positioned to gain market share, Cowen analyst John Kernan said in a report Monday. But Fitbit's rising expenses are likely to ding earnings next year, he said.Kernan cut his price target on Fitbit stock to 18 from 20 and maintained his market perform rating. Fitbit stock closed down 0.4% to 14.78 on the stock market today."Our survey data indicates consumer adoption of fitness wearables remains on a rising trend with Fitbit dominating the market, which should support future unit growth albeit with somewhat unpredictable product cycles," Kernan said. "Consensus margin forecasts for fiscal 2017 are optimistic given the cost of funding global growth."IBD'S TAKE: Fitbit ranks No. 10 out of 11 companies in IBD's Consumer Products-Electronic industry group. To see which company leads the sector, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Cowen survey data shows adoption of fitness wearables is increasing among those who exercise. Fitbit had 49% usage share with that group in August, followed by Nike (NKE) (33%), Apple (AAPL) (20%), Under Armour (UA) (18%) and Garmin (GRMN) (13%).The Cowen survey showed Apple's Apple Watch making gains in the market, while Nike and Under Armour lost ground for their devices and mobile apps.Kernan said his estimate for Fitbit's 2016 earnings per share is within management's guidance. But he believes consensus EPS estimates are too high for 2017.Kernan lowered his 2017 EPS estimate for Fitbit to $1.29, below consensus of $1.43. He believes Fitbit's sales and marketing expenses will be higher than expected by Wall Street as the company increases its presence worldwide.RELATED:Fitbit Downgraded On Charge 2 Reception, Apple Watch Win

Stocks opened lower Thursday, despite better-than-expected unemployment and export price data in the U.S.Dow industrials fell 1% while the S&P 500 lost 1.1% and the Nasdaq shed 1.3%. Treasury yields fell.Global markets had shifted lower earlier, after data showed a surprise drop in China's September imports and a deeper-than-expected decline in exports. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index tumbled 1.6%, but China's Shanghai Composite ended with a 0.1% gain. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 slipped 0.4%.Global mining issues were taking a beating, sending Europe's markets lower. European financials also were under pressure, apparently due to analyst downgrades. The DAX in Frankfurt fell 1.6%, the CAC 40 in Paris dropped 1.8% in afternoon trade. London's FTSE 100 showed a 1.3% loss.Mining issues lagged, with Freeport McMoRan (FCX), Vale (VALE) and Rio Tinto (RIO) down 4% to 8%.Merck (MRK) rose nearly 1% on the Dow. Pfizer (PFE) fell more than 1% after losing a U.K. appeals court case attempting to defend its Lyrica patent vs. generic drug maker Actavis.Garmin (GRMN) fell 2.3%.On the IBD 50 list, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) had a near-6% gain. The salon and beauty supplies chain raised its third-quarter earnings guidance to well above analyst consensus views. The stock is shaping a tight, second-stage base pattern below a late-August high.Gigamon (GIMO) initially climbed 1%, but reversed to trade down more than 1%. The stock found support at its 50-day moving average in Wednesday's session, but had seen some heavy selling in its pullback from a Sept. 27 high.Initial jobless claims slowed to 246,000 in the week ended Oct. 8, the Labor Department reported. That was down slightly from the prior week's 249,000 claims and well below consensus views for an uptick to 254,000 claims. The four-week moving average also downshifted, to 249,250 -- a fourth straight decease.Export prices rose a better-than-expected 0.3% in September, reversing August's 0.8% decline and besting views for a 0.1% increase. Import prices rose 0.1%, in line with consensus views.The Energy Information Administration releases weekly natural gas inventory data at 10:30 a.m. ET and its weekly oil report 30 minutes later. The Treasury Department's September budget is set for a 2 p.m. ET release.Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank President Patrick Harker speaks at 12:15 p.m. ET.Oil prices held steady, with West Texas Intermediate just above $50 a barrel and Brent crude just below $52. Gold inched up to $1,260 an ounce. The dollar eased vs. the euro and the yen. Bonds edged up, trimming the 10-year Treasury yield 3 basis points to 1.74%.

Fitbit (FIT), the leading maker of wearable activity trackers, saw its stock continue to climb Thursday amid reports of increasing adoption of fitness bands and watches.Fitbit shares rose 3% to 16.76 on the stock market today, touching a four-month high intraday.IBD'S TAKE: Fitbit stock broke out of a flat base on Monday. For an analysis of the stock's recent performance, read the article titled "Can Fitbit Hold Its Fledgling Breakout?"A report out Thursday from Parks Associates showed that 18% of U.S. broadband households own a wearable fitness device such as a smartwatch or a fitness tracker.Parks said 12% of U.S. broadband homes own a fitness tracker, such as those made by Fitbit and Garmin (GRMN). That's up from 10% in the third quarter of last year.Adoption of smartwatches with fitness features doubled to 8% in the demographic from 4% in Q3 last year, Parks said. Apple (AAPL) dominates the smartwatch with its Apple Watch. Apple released a second-generation version of its Apple Watch last Friday."Adoption for fitness trackers and smartwatches continues to accelerate," Harry Wang, senior director of research for Parks Associates, said in a statement. "Our research shows that there is little overlap between these two sets of owners, and smartwatch owners are more likely to use the device during rigorous activities such as running, biking or swimming."The newly released Apple Watch 2 capitalizes on such user needs by adding GPS and waterproof functions, a smart move by Apple," Wang said.Device abandonment continues to be a concern in the fitness wearables market.After one year of ownership, 17% of fitness tracker owners quit using the device, Parks said. That compares with 8% of smartwatch owners who quit using the device after a year.Baird analyst William Power on Wednesday reiterated his neutral rating on Fitbit stock, with a price target of 16."Our quarterly activity tracker survey suggested slightly lower overall interest in activity trackers, though Fitbit's share and brand loyalty remained strong and grew year over year," Power said. "Separately, our semiannual Fitbit customer-engagement survey suggested slackening usage patterns relative to past surveys."RELATED:Lower-Priced Apple Watch 1 Might Outsell New Apple Watch 2 This HolidayFitbit Exercises Its Dominance In Wearables As Apple Wheezes

Apple's (AAPL) iPhone 7 could make people think twice about buying a separate action camera from the likes of GoPro (GPRO), says Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brad Erickson."The camera on the new phone features 4K video recording at 30 frames per second, uses improved optical image stabilization and is water resistant," Erickson said in a research note late Wednesday. "While action cameras still serve a very specific and desired purpose in capturing moments and experiences where a smartphone is not practical or possible, that iPhone 7 offers such high-quality video, in line with the (GoPro) Hero 4 Black, and is at least a bit more resistant to the elements, could cause consumers to question the purchase of an incremental camera for activities where a phone won't cut it."While not technically waterproof, the water-resistant iPhone 7 can survive being under 3 feet of water for 30 minutes.GoPro stock fell 2.2% to 13.58 on the stock market today. On Wednesday, after the iPhone 7 was announced, GoPro stock dropped 4.7%.IBD'S TAKE: GoPro stock is heavily out of favor, carrying an IBD Composite Rating of just 19. To see which stocks lead IBD's Consumer Products-Electronic industry group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup."A better camera on the water-resistant iPhone may make GoPro's presumptive Hero 5 a bit less compelling this holiday," Erickson said. He rates GoPro stock as sector weight, or neutral.GoPro is expected to unveil its next-generation action camera, the Hero 5, and its first flying-camera drone, Karma, on Sept. 19.The latest teaser video for Karma implies that the drone is small, silent and highly maneuverable, which could be a game changer in the drone market. Top consumer drone makers in the U.S. market today are DJI, Yuneec, 3DR and Parrot.GoPro's drone is intended to expand the category, Dougherty analyst Charles Anderson said in a report Wednesday. It will compete with market leader DJI by being easier to use, he said."Management believes it will be the more user-friendly drone on the market and the easiest to pack/travel with," he said. Anderson rates GoPro stock as neutral.Erickson says Apple's second-generation smartwatch, the Apple Watch Series 2, also could be a drag on wearable fitness device makers Fitbit (FIT) and Garmin (GRMN).The "refreshed Apple Watch's clear focus on fitness does not bode well for Garmin or Fitbit," Erickson said.The Apple Watch 2 has onboard GPS and is water resistant to a depth of 50 meters.The fact that the new Apple Watch features hiking, running and swimming applications hits right at the heart of Garmin's sports watch portfolio, Erickson says. Fitbit, which sells more wearable activity trackers than watches, is less affected by the Apple Watch 2, he says.Erickson rates Fitbit and Garmin shares as sector weight.RELATED:What Investors Loved, Hated About Apple iPhone 7 Event

Shares of Fitbit (FIT) and Garmin (GRMN) are both tracking down Thursday following the prior day's introduction of the Apple (AAPL) Watch Series 2.The new Apple Watch -- a "swim proof" wearable with a built-in GPS, brighter display and "Pokemon Go" -- seems to be aiming for the fitness crowd. The company also unveiled a special Nike (NKE) edition of the smartwatch geared toward running enthusiasts.As with all Apple events, the social space went wild upon hearing the news.Is it sad I'm only wanna get the Apple Watch for Pokemon GO? 😂— Joey Graceffa (@JoeyGraceffa) September 8, 2016The announcement sent Fitbit shares 2% lower Wednesday, and shares down another 0.5% in the stock market today. Garmin shares fell 0.4% Thursday, after edging up 0.2% Wednesday.The Watch Series 2 from Apple starts at $369, a far cry from the $149.95 for Fitbit's new Charge 2 and the $249.95 for its most expensive device. But the price difference doesn't appear to take the Apple Watch out of the running for those considering a wearable purchase.
Goodbye Fitbit hello Apple Watch 2 😍— Alina Juarez (@alinaaaaxd) September 8, 2016
Even before Wednesday's unveiling, the Apple Watch and Fitbit were already in direct contention.
Does anyone have input regarding the Apple Watch versus the Fitbit Blaze and Surge?Looking at all three and I'm... https://t.co/yxrkQtS3gi— Jeffery Ballard (@JefferyBallard) August 28, 2016

Thinking about either getting a Fitbit or an Apple Watch. Suggestions? Pros and Cons?— Ashley Schmitt (@UKgirl_ash0104) August 28, 2016And now that the original Apple Watch has been discounted to $269, that might make the decision even tougher, even as Fitbit maintains its place as the wearables market-share leader.IBD's TAKE: Apple shares are down, but the stock's 50-day line recently converged above its 200-day line, meaning that it is forming a proper buy point. To learn what that means, watch IBD's chart analysis here: "Apple Finally Shapes A Buy Point; Watch Broadcom, Activision."Meanwhile, Nike shares slid 2.7% Thursday, but that likely has less to do with Apple and more to do with the downgrade it received from Piper Jaffray. The firm cut its rating to neutral from overweight.Athletic apparel rival Under Armour (UA) shares retreated 1.4%.RELATED:Adidas Isn't The Only Comeback Kid Nike Has To Worry AboutApple Debuts Fitness-Centric Apple Watch Series 2 With 'Pokemon Go' Fitbit Exercises Its Dominance In Wearables As Apple Wheezes

The growth in wearable health and fitness devices is providing a boom market for makers of wireless connectivity semiconductors. Shipments of wireless chips for health and fitness devices will reach a projected 61.2 million units this year, up 11% over 2013, IHS Technology said in a report Thursday. It sees shipments climbing 12% in 2015 to 68.5 million units and…

Stock futures climbed hard ahead of Wednesday's open, as news from the eurozone and Greece continued to dominate the holiday-shortened trading week.Dow futures soared 162.5 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures leapt 40 points. S&P 500 futures powered up 16.1 points.Global markets turned optimistic on news that a letter from Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras acceded to the austerity measures demanded by eurozone creditors, but with several critical changes.Tsipras asked for an extension of the prior bailout arrangement, which expired at midnight following the default on Greece's debt payment owed to the International Monetary Fund. The letter also requested an additional $32.3 billion in bailout funds.European leaders gave a mixed review to Tsipras' offer, which was received as central bankers were preparing to restrict access by Greek banks to emergency loans, according to the Financial Times.The reaction among European markets was not mixed, with the CAC-40 in Paris up 2.6% and Frankfurt's DAX ahead 2.5% just after midday.The U.S. stock market today received a slug of early economic news, beginning with the Challenger Job Cut report. Consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas said employers announced almost 45,000 job cuts in June — 43% above the year-ago level. That pushed the midyear total for layoffs to its highest since 2010. The retail sector posted the most job cuts in June, the report said, primarily due to the closing of Target (TGT) stores in Canada.The ADP National Employment report showed U.S. nonfarm private employer added 237,000 jobs in June. That was a healthy step up from 201,000 new hires in May and well above consensus forecasts for additions of 220,000. Of the June gains, 225,000 were service sector jobs.At 10 a.m. ET, the Institute for Supply Management releases its June Manufacturing Index, and the Commerce Department delivers May construction spending data. Automakers will be releasing June auto sales tallies throughout the day.In stocks, insurance mergers made news for a second day this week, with New Jersey-based Chubb (CB) soaring 32% ahead of the open on news that Switzerland-based Ace (ACE) will acquire the company in a $28.3 billion cash-stock deal. Ace shares rose 7%.On the IBD 50 list, leaders were generally flat to higher. Israel's CyberArk Software (CYBR), Ambarella (AMBA) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) ran at the head of the group, up 2% each in premarket trade.In China, the Shanghai Composite continued its recent volatile streak, backing down 5.2% after regulators did not alter the standing policy on IPO approvals. The Hong Kong Exchange was closed Wednesday. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 edged 0.5% lower.The dollar rose vs. both the euro and the yen. Oil dropped more than 1%. Gold eased a fraction. Wheat dropped 2%.

Garmin (GRMN), a maker of satellite navigation gear and devices for fitness and outdoor enthusiasts, saw its stock tumble Wednesday after being downgraded by Pacific Crest Securities. Pacific Crest analyst Brad Erickson cut his rating on Garmin to underperform from sector perform, citing a bunch of risks to the stock. He said Wall Street is overestimating the upside potential for…

Samsung Electronics is reportedly working with sports clothing maker Under Armour (UA) for the development of wearable fitness devices, according to a South Korean media outlet.The Yonhap News Agency said Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank reportedly met with Samsung Vice Chairman Lee Jay-yong this month, citing "market sources" as providing the information. They reportedly discussed ways of countering the impact from collaboration between Apple (AAPL) and Nike (NKE) in the wearable device sector.Samsung is the top seller of smartwatches with its Gear devices that use the Google (GOOGL) Android operating system, followed by Sony (SNE) and Pebble, according to ABI Research. Samsung also sells its Gear Fit, used for tracking fitness.This category, known as activity trackers, currently outsells smartwatches. ABI Research expects 10 million activity trackers and 7 million smartwatches to be shipped in 2014.In the first quarter, the top vendor in the activity tracker field was FitBit, followed by Garmin (GRMN) and Nike.Apple is expected to introduce a smartwatch/fitness tracker in September or October, dubbed the iWatch. Apple has also been working with Nike in developing smart devices since 2006. Nike's wearable FuelBand activity tracker works with Apple products.Under Armour released its own fitness tracker, the Armour39 system, last year.Early this year, Samsung introduced its Galaxy Gear Fit.Under Armour was down 1.5% in late-afternoon trading in the stock market today.Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter @IBD_BDeagon.RELATED:Analysts Including iWatch In Apple Estimates, Before Product Even Announced.

The major stock indexes continued to push ahead Friday afternoon and have retraced the bulk of Thursday's losses.Chips, software, solar and biotech helped lift the Nasdaq to a 1.3% gain. The S&P 500 rose 0.8%. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.6%. Despite options expiration, volume was running mixed in the stock market today. NYSE volume was tracking sharply higher but Nasdaq trade was running lower.Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) stretched its gain to 15%. Its stock is now 24% past a 42.59 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. The maker of analog semiconductors for smartphones and other devices reported late Thursday that its fiscal Q3 EPS topped the upper end of its own guidance, which it had raised last month. Revenue easily cleared forecasts, and management hoisted Q4 revenue guidance to well above consensus views.After fading badly Thursday, Fairchild Semiconductor (FCS) rallied 5%. The stock is pennies away from its June 17 peak, but it has already extended from a rebound off its 10-week moving average. On Thursday, the chipmaker reported Q2 results above views.Blackstone Group (BX) rallied 3% to its best levels in more than seven years. The stock has staged a nice comeback from a failed breakout earlier this month with a 34.19 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. It's now 3% past the 34.19 trigger. On Thursday, the asset manager delivered Q2 earnings that more than doubled from a year ago, thanks to a jump in performance fees.On the downside, Michael Kors (KORS) fell 1% after erasing a near 2% gain. Jefferies lowered the stock's price target to 80 from 95.
Stocks groaned lower in hectic early trade Wednesday, following the lead of global markets after China continued letting its currency fall in line with currency market influences.
The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average slumped 1.3% each. The S&P 500 dropped 1.2%.
Volume rose, up 8% on the Nasdaq and 3% higher on the NYSE, compared with volume levels at the same time Tuesday.

The stock market today launched with the S&P 500 tearing a hole in support at its 200-day moving average, around the 2075 level. The index took a quick breath of air above its 50-day line on Monday and Tuesday before dropping back into its repeated pattern of 200-day tests begun June 29. In that time the index has finished two sessions below that line of support, on July 8 and 9. The Nasdaq is trading just below its 50-day moving average.
U.S. economic news was relatively minor, with the Labor Department's June Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey narrowing to 5.24 million unfilled positions vs. 5.35 million open jobs in May.

New York Federal Reserve chief William Dudley, speaking in Rochester, N.Y., said it was early to judge what was going on in China, that the country's currency could have been appreciating alongside the dollar and in need of adjustment.
"Obviously if the Chinese economy is weaker than maybe what the Chinese authorities anticipated, it's probably not inappropriate for the currency to adjust in consequence to that weakness," he said.
The Energy Information Administration reports weekly oil inventories at 10:30 a.m. ET. The Treasury Department reports its July budget at 2 p.m.
The Dow opened almost unanimously lower. Only Chevron (CVX) rose, up 0.2%, aided by a 1% rebound in oil prices. Apple (AAPL), Nike (NKE), JPMorgan (JPM) and Boeing (BA) fell more than 2%.

On the S&P 500, Fossil (FOSL) and Yahoo (YHOO) were worst hit, down 5% each. Fossil reported weaker-than-expected Q2 revenue growth and Q3 guidance. Yahoo's drop is likely attributable to its 384 million share stake in Alibaba, which has said it will spin off at some point as a separately traded entity.

At the top of the S&P 500, banking and payment software technologies firm Fidelity National Information Services (FIS) jumped nearly 6% after announcing it would pay $9.1 billion to acquire SunGard Data Systems. The privately held SunGard had registered for an initial public offering in June. The company reported $4.67 billion debt as of June 30. National reported that the cash-stock deal would create a company with $9.2 billion in combined revenue. Wednesday's gain hoisted shares to just below a 68.99 buy point in a shallow, five-month cup base.

China-based e-retail giant Alibaba (BABA) retreated 7% in opening trade after its second-quarter earnings narrowly topped expectations, while a 28% revenue jump stopped short of projections and the growth of total gross volume slowed to 34%. Management launched a two-year, $4.6 billion share buyback initiative. The loss put shares 40% below their November high and 6% above their September IPO price.

Among leaders, Ambarella (AMBA), a leading developer of video processing chips, skidded 4% lower, to the bottom of the IBD 50 list. Key client GoPro (GPRO) was also 4% lower in early trade. Ambarella is struggling to hold its 50-day line of support for a second time in a month.Stocks groaned lower in hectic early trade Wednesday, following the lead of global markets after China continued letting its currency fall in line with currency market influences.The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average slumped 1.3% each. Fossil reported weaker-than-expected Q2 revenue growth and Q3 guidance. Yahoo's drop is likely attributable to its 384 million share stake in Alibaba, which has said it will spin off at some point as a separately traded entity.At the top of the S&P 500, banking and payment software technologies firm Fidelity National Information Services (FIS) jumped nearly 6% after announcing it would pay $9.1 billion to acquire SunGard Data Systems. The privately held SunGard had registered for an initial public offering in June. The company reported $4.67 billion debt as of June 30. National reported that the cash-stock deal would create a company with $9.2 billion in combined revenue. Wednesday's gain hoisted shares to just below a 68.99 buy point in a shallow, five-month cup base.China-based e-retail giant Alibaba (BABA) retreated 7% in opening trade after its second-quarter earnings narrowly topped expectations, while a 28% revenue jump stopped short of projections and the growth of total gross volume slowed to 34%. Management launched a two-year, $4.6 billion share buyback initiative. The loss put shares 40% below their November high and 6% above their September IPO price.Among leaders, Ambarella (AMBA), a leading developer of video processing chips, skidded 4% lower, to the bottom of the IBD 50 list. Key client GoPro (GPRO) was also 4% lower in early trade. Ambarella is struggling to hold its 50-day line of support for a second time in a month.
Stocks pulled together some nice gains early Wednesday, as investors ignored weak housing data ahead of this afternoon's release of Fed minutes.
The Dow Jones industrial and the Nasdaq climbed 0.6% each. The S&P 500 grabbed a 0.5% gain.
Volume was quietly mixed, up 3% on the Nasdaq and 11% lower on the NYSE, relative to trade at the same time Tuesday.

The stock market today got off to a reasonably healthy start, despite Commerce Department data showing October housing starts slumped to a seven-month low. The market will be tuned to the 2 p.m. ET release of minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's Oct. 28 meeting, seeking any signs of timing on an interest rate increase.
Dow stocks were mostly positive. Apple (AAPL) pounded out a 3% gain to top the group after being added to Goldman Sachs' conviction buy list.
Norfolk Southern (NSC) led the S&P 500, up nearly 6% after Canadian Pacific Railway (CP) offered to buy the rail peer in a cash stock deal valued at more than $28 billion.

ConAgra (CAG) rallied more than 5%. The Omaha, Neb.-based packaged food giant announced it would strip out its frozen potato business, separating it under the Lamb Weston name at the beginning of next year.
U.K.-based oil driller Ensco (ESV) was close behind with a gain of nearly 5%. Energy stocks made a strong showing in early action, as oil prices rose modestly.
An array of retail stocks posted mixed early moves following their quarterly reports. The Energy Information Administration reports its weekly inventories data at 10:30 a.m.
China-based Vipshop (VIPS) spiked 10%. Jack in the Box (JACK) climbed 3%. Staples (SPLS) slipped 2%. Target (TGT) gave up its premarket gain and slumped 3% after reporting third-quarter results.

Among leaders, healthcare staffing agency AMN Healthcare (AHS) rumbled up 6% at the start of trade. The San Diego-based operation said late Tuesday it agreed to buy privately held B.E. Smith for $160 million in cash. AMN said the deal would be immediately accretive to its adjusted EPS. The stock has been scrawling out an erratic pattern and attempting to regain support its 10-week moving average.

Citrix Systems (CTXS) shed 8% in early action. The developer of enterprise software solutions announced late Tuesday it would lay off 1,000 workers and spin off its GoTo unit as a separate business. The company said the moves would result in pretax charges of up to $85 million and create savings of $200 million per year. Stocks struggled in narrowly mixed formation again Wednesday, this time with techs slightly lagging the overall market.
The Nasdaq drooped 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.2% and the S&P 500 fought to hold a 0.1% gain.
Volume was soft, down 12% on the Nasdaq and 19% lower on the NYSE vs. trade at the same time Tuesday.

The stock market today opened to weaker-than-expected January housing data, which compounded a surprise drop in builder confidence reported Tuesday. Building-related stocks weathered the news with only narrow losses.

Earnings reports drove a large share of early action. Fertilizer producer CF Industries (CF) popped 8%, GPS toolmaker Garmin (GRMN) and drilling contractor Nabors (NBR) each jumped up 9%. La-Z-Boy (LZB) dived 7% and FreightCar America (RAIL) slid 6%.

Among leaders, Spirit Airlines (SAVE) bolted 6% to an early lead among IBD 50 stocks. The Florida-based airline reported Q4 EPS up 107% vs. forecasts for an 85% gain. Revenue rose 28%, just a shade below projections. The gap-up gain put shares just below the 51.95 high in the fifth week of a flat consolidation.

Beyond earnings reports, drugmaker Eli Lilly (LLY) gapped up to a 3% gain in heavy trade. The company reported its experimental lung cancer treatment ramucirumab improved survival rates in a late-stage trial.

Steel maker U.S. Steel (X) slumped 6% after a Commerce Department decision late Tuesday not to impose tariffs on steel pipe imported from South Korea. Luxembourg-based Tenaris (TS) dropped 5%, possibly due to the same news. Steel pipe has seen heavy demand from U.S. pipeline and energy production companies.
