Longtop Financial Technologies (LFT) erased opening gains and shed 7% in heavy trading, snapping a five-session win streak.
On the economic calendar for Thursday are initial jobless claims, productivity and unit labor costs.

Earnings for Thursday will include AECOM Technology (ACM), DG FastChannel (DGIT), DirecTV (DTV), Goldcorp (GG), Hansen Natural (HANS), Royal Gold (RGLD), SXC Health Solutions (SXCI), Thomson Reuters (TRI) and Tower Group (TWGP).
Also Thursday, retailers will post April sales results and jobless claims data will be released.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Rise; Nasdaq Ekes Out Gain
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks finished higher Wednesday as reports found that the pace of job losses slowed. Easing worries over banks also helped.

The NYSE composite climbed 2.1%, the S&P 500 1.7% and the Dow 1.2%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq rose 0.3%, thanks to a last-minute push. The tech-heavy index had been down as much as 1.3% and up as much as 0.9%.
Volume climbed sharply on both exchanges.
Regional banks were among the biggest winners. SunTrust Banks (STI) jumped 15%, while PNC Financial Services (PNC) and BB&T (BBT) gained 12% each.
Energy and gold producers also scored nice gains.
Retail, homebuilders and apparel were some of Wednesday's biggest decliners.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks March Ahead; Nasdaq Turns Green
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks ramped up in late trade Wednesday. Even the Nasdaq turned positive.
The NYSE composite ran 2.1%, the S&P 500 1.7%, the Dow 1.2% and the Nasdaq 0.4%.
According to media reports, American Express (AXP), Bank of New York Mellon (BK) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) passed government stress tests. They rose between 4% and 10%.
Turnover continued to track vastly higher across the board.
True Religion Apparel (TRLG) extended its gain to 26%. But the maker of high-priced jeans still sits about 30% off a 52-week high.
Recent IPO Changyou.com (CYOU) reversed earlier losses and rose 2%. The Chinese Internet gaming firm has yet to form its first base.
2:15 p.m. Update: Comeback Loses Steam In Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes weakened with a couple of hours left in Wednesday's session.

The NYSE composite was up 1.1%, S&P 500 0.8% and Dow 0.5%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq fell 0.6%. Tech bellwether Cisco Systems (CSCO) slipped 2% ahead of its earnings report after the close. Analysts see profit falling 33% to 25 cents a share.
Volume was again running higher across the board.

Garmin (GRMN) gapped below its 200-day moving average and tumbled 15%. Before the open, the GPS device maker reported a 63% drop in Q1 earnings and a 34% decline in sales. Both were larger than expected.

Powell Industries (POWL) shed 10% in hefty trading, erasing gains from a three-session win streak. Earlier Wednesday, the maker of power management systems beat views with a 45% rise in first-quarter earnings. But sales grew only 2%, below views. And Powell guided full-year profit and revenue below analysts' estimates.

AngloGold Ashanti (AU) gapped up and rallied 10%. The stock is working on the right side of a cup base within a bigger consolidation. Analysts see the South African gold producer earning $2.65 a share this year, up from four prior years of losses.
Banks held nice gains ahead of Thursday's results from government stress tests.
Bank of America (BAC) rallied 13%, Wells Fargo (WFC) 11%, and Citigroup (C) climbed 9%.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Improve; Nasdaq Pares Losses
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks remained mixed in early afternoon trading Wednesday, but conditions have improved.

The NYSE composite climbed 1.2% thanks to gains in financials and energy. The S&P 500 and Dow rose 0.9% and 0.6%, respectively. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq trimmed its loss to 0.4%. It was down 1.3% at the session low.
Turnover was again tracking higher across the board. Despite the improvement, leaders up in volume were few.
MercadoLibre (MELI) rose 3% in fast trade ahead of its Q1 results after the close. The Latin e-commerce firm is expected to earn 10 cents a share on sales of $32.9 million.
On the downside, many retailers fell ahead of April same-store sales data due out Thursday.
Aeropostale (ARO) fell 4% in brisk trading. The teen apparel retailer turned tail after hitting an all-time high. Since bottoming in December the stock has been on a tear, tripling in price.
Ross Stores (ROST) reversed early gains and lost 3%. The discount clothing and accessories retailer cleared a cup-with-handle base April 22, but the breakout failed five sessions later.
Elsewhere, Beacon Roofing Supply (BECN) fell 4% as it continued to give back gains from a recent breakout. The stock passed a 15.15 buy point April 29.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Remain Mixed At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks remained mixed at midday Wednesday, as techs and small caps lagged.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite slid 0.3%, while the small-cap S&P 600 dropped 0.5%. On the upside, the S&P 500 gained 0.8%, the Dow industrials 0.5% and the NYSE composite 1.2%.
Volume ramped up across the board. It swelled 8% on the NYSE and 5% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.
True Religion Apparel  (TRLG) added to its early gains, surging 23% in huge volume. The maker of high-end jeans and other clothing continues to rally after a blowout earnings report.
On the downside, Pegasystems (PEGA) slid 5% in three times its normal trade. The maker of business process management software rocketed 41% in massive volume Tuesday after a bullish earnings report.

Netflix  (NFLX) lost 6% in rapid turnover. The provider of online movie rentals has fallen 14% since hitting a new high April 13. It has found support at its 50-day moving average so far on Wednesday. Look for possible signs of strength from here, such as a potential rebound in brisk volume.
Allegiant Travel (ALGT) skidded 5% in heavy volume. The resort-destination airline priced an offering of 2.3 million shares at $50 each.
11:15 a.m. Update: Major Indexes Trade Mixed

Stocks piled on more losses Wednesday as European debt worries again took center stage. Moody's warned that it could downgrade Portugal's credit rating.

The NYSE composite dropped 1.1%, falling further south of its 50-day moving average. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 fell 0.9% and 0.7%, respectively. Both breached their 50-day lines. The Dow lost 0.5%, but remained just above its 50-day line. Volume fell on both exchanges.
The dollar again surged, while the euro hit a 14-month low. Crude oil dropped $2.77 to $79.97 a barrel. But gold gained $5.80 to $1175 an ounce.
Sirona Dental Systems (SIRO) dived 14% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The stock also fell below a 38.88 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.

China Automotive Systems (CAAS) gapped down and tumbled 9% in nearly double its normal trade. It was down more than 14% at session low. The Chinese auto parts maker reports Q1 results Thursday before the open. Analysts see its earnings jumping 138% to 19 cents a share.
EZCorp (EZPW) slumped nearly 9% in more than double its average volume. The stock has now fallen more than 8% from a 22.29 buy point from a flat base.

Guess (GES) dropped 5% in heavy turnover. But it closed well off its session low and above its 200-day moving average. Late Tuesday, the apparel maker announced the resignation of its president and chief operating officer. The stock had been down nearly 12%.

In after-hours news, Boston Beer (SAM) rose just over 1% after delivering Q1 earnings ahead of analysts' estimates. But Career Education (CECO) fell 1%, despite reporting first-quarter profit ahead of analysts' estimates.
Earnings Thursday: AboveNet (ABVT), Big 5 Sporting Goods (BGFV), DirecTV (DTV), Dr. Pepper Snapple Group (DPS), EZchip (EZCH), SXC Health Solutions (SXCI) and MercadoLibre (MELI) .
Reports on weekly jobless claims and productivity will also be out Thursday.
U.S. Stocks Fall Again, But End Off Worst Levels
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks stumbled for a second session Wednesday, but closed off session lows.
The NYSE composite shed 1.1%, up from a 1.8% deficit. The Nasdaq fell 0.9%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the Dow 0.5%. Of the four major indexes, only the Dow remains above its 50-day moving average.
According to preliminary data, volume edged up across the board. Decliners outpaced advancers nearly 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq and about 4-to-1 on the NYSE.

Of IBD's 197 industry groups, only a dozen or so rose. Transportation equipment makers and household-related groups were the session's worst performers. Medical-related and banks were among some groups that bucked the trend.
U.S. Stocks Further Weaken In Late Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks further weakened but were still off session lows in late trading Wednesday.
The NYSE composite lost 1.2%. The Nasdaq dropped 1% while the Dow and the S&P 500 lost 0.8% each. Volume was mixed, with NYSE trading tracking higher and Nasdaq turnover a touch lower.

DG FastChannel (DGIT) was off its intraday peak, but still up 10% on huge volume. Before the open, the provider of digital advertising services beat views with a 116% pop in Q1 earnings and a 31% gain in sales.

Sanmina-SCI (SANM) erased earlier losses and climbed 5% in heavy trading. The stock neared its 50-day moving average, which it sliced Tuesday. Sanmina-SCI makes circuit boards and other electronic components. It lost 52 cents a share last year, but analysts are expecting a profit of $1.20 a share this year.
Career Education (CECO) also reversed and climbed 2% ahead of its earnings report after the close. Analysts are expecting 64 cents a share, up 64%.
Copa Holdings (CPA) and Boston Beer (SAM) also report quarterly results after the close. They fell 3% and 1%, respectively.
U.S. Stocks Weaken A Bit; Trade Turns Mixed
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks were again lower and have slightly weakened since the prior update.
The Nasdaq and NYSE composite dropped 0.6% each. The Dow fell 0.4% and the S&P 500 0.3%. Volume was again tracking higher on the NYSE. Nasdaq volume turned a tad lower.

Garmin (GRMN) gapped below its 50-day moving average and dived 10% in heavy trading. Before the open, the GPS maker reported a 52% rise in Q1 earnings, but missed views. Sales fell 1%, also below views.
EZCorp (EZPW) slumped 7%, falling further south of its 50-day moving average. The stock has now fallen more than 8% from a 22.29 buy point from a flat base.

Guess (GES) was off its session low, but still down 4% in heavy trading. Late Tuesday, the apparel maker announced the resignation of its president and chief operating officer. The stock had been down nearly 12%.

On the upside, Coinstar (CSTR) reversed morning losses and ran 6% to a new record high. Last week, the firm smashed views with a 254% surge in Q1 earnings and raised its full-year outlook. Coinstar operates coin-counting machines and the Redbox DVD rental service.

Grand Canyon Education (LOPE) erased early losses and climbed 3% in fast trade. Late Tuesday, the online education firm reported Q1 earnings and sales above views. But the company gave a weak Q2 profit outlook.
U.S. Stocks Lower, But Off Worst Levels
BY VINCENT MAO
Major stock indexes were lower in unison after an earlier stab into mixed territory faltered. Still, stocks remained well off the session's worst levels.
The Nasdaq fell 0.6%, up from a 1.7% shortfall. The NYSE composite lost 0.5%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Dow 0.3%. Turnover was tracking higher on both exchanges.

Telestone Technologies (TTEC) shed 8% and sliced its 200-day moving average. The stock had been above the long-term support line for more than a year. It's a market laggard, though, with a 13 in Relative Strength. That puts it near the bottom eighth of the market in price performance.
Rue21 (RUE)was off its session low, but still down 4%. It's back under its 50-day moving average. The stock is working on a new base following its March breakout.

On the upside, HSN (HSNI) gapped up and bolted 9% on strong earnings. Before the open, the operator of the Home Shopping Network trounced views with a 350% pop in Q1 profit. Revenue grew 9%, also above views.

OpenTable (OPEN) gapped up and climbed nearly 7% in heavy trade. Late Tuesday, the provider of restaurant reservations beat views with a 180% surge in Q1 earnings. Sales rose 33%, also above views. That also marked the third straight quarter of acceleration. The May 2009 IPO recently found support at its 10-week moving average.
U.S. Stocks Turn Mixed At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes snapped back from early losses at midday Wednesday, as bargain hunters swooped in following Tuesday's sell-off.
The S&P 500 and Dow both rose 0.1%. On the downside, the Nasdaq fell 0.2% and the NYSE composite 0.1%. Volume was up 13% on the NYSE and 2% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.

Sirona Dental Systems (SIRO) plunged 10% in massive volume. The dental equipment maker posted fiscal second-quarter revenue of $190.1 million, topping projections of $184.9 million. But earnings results missed views, sending the stock down to its 50-day moving average.

China Integrated Energy (CBEH) dropped 6% in nearly triple its usual turnover. The Chinese oil exploration, production and distribution firm's stock also sank to its 50-day moving average, though it found support at that level.

True Religion Apparel (TRLG) also lost 6% in heavy trade. The upscale jeans maker topped first-quarter sales and earnings estimates after Tuesday's close. But a Lazard Capital analyst downgrade the stock to hold from buy, citing valuation concerns triggered by the broad market's recent decline.

The May 2009 IPO recently found support at its 10-week moving average.U.S. Stocks Turn Mixed At MiddayBY JONAH KERIThe major indexes snapped back from early losses at midday Wednesday, as bargain hunters swooped in following Tuesday's sell-off.The S&P 500 and Dow both rose 0.1%. On the downside, the Nasdaq fell 0.2% and the NYSE composite 0.1%. Volume was up 13% on the NYSE and 2% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday.Sirona Dental Systems (SIRO) plunged 10% in massive volume. The dental equipment maker posted fiscal second-quarter revenue of $190.1 million, topping projections of $184.9 million. But earnings results missed views, sending the stock down to its 50-day moving average.China Integrated Energy (CBEH) dropped 6% in nearly triple its usual turnover. The Chinese oil exploration, production and distribution firm's stock also sank to its 50-day moving average, though it found support at that level.True Religion Apparel (TRLG) also lost 6% in heavy trade. The upscale jeans maker topped first-quarter sales and earnings estimates after Tuesday's close. But a Lazard Capital analyst downgrade the stock to hold from buy, citing valuation concerns triggered by the broad market's recent decline.U.S. Stocks Pare Losses After ISM Report

5:15 p.m. Update: A big drop in consumer confidence handed stocks their biggest losses in more than two weeks Tuesday. Already weak at the open, equities piled on losses after the Conference Board's consumer confidence index came in at 46 vs. expectations of 55.

The NYSE composite dropped 1.5%. The Nasdaq shed 1.3% and sliced its 50-day moving average. Chip issues were a drag on the tech-laden index. The Philadelphia semiconductor index shed 2.8%. Highly ranked chip issues such as SanDisk (SNDK) and Hittite Microwave (HITT) dropped 4% each. Cree (CREE) and NetLogic Microsystems (NETL) fell 3% apiece.
Meanwhile, the S&P 500 fell 1.2%, closing back under the 1100 level. And the Dow lost 1%. Volume grew sharply on both exchanges.

IPC The Hospitalist (IPCM) gapped below its 50-day moving average and tumbled 9% in huge volume. Late Monday, the hospital services provider guided full-year 2010 sales below views. The stock was down as much as 17%, but trimmed losses after hitting its 200-day moving average.
MercadoLibre (MELI) gapped down and and lost 7% in more than triple its average volume. Late Monday, the Latin e-commerce firm reported Q4 earnings and sales below views.

On the upside, Tri-Tech Holding (TRIT) reversed higher and gained more than 6% in heavy trading. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to B+ from C+ late last month. Tri-Tech is a Chinese water engineering, consulting and management firm. It has logged triple-digit earnings increases for the past two quarters.
Whole Foods Market (WFMI) reversed morning losses and rose 3% in more than twice its average volume. The stock touched a 21-month high.
Pegasystems (PEGA) made a huge comeback to finish fractionally higher. The software maker was down as much as 11% after Roth Capital downgraded shares.

Earnings Wednesday: Aegean Marine Petroleum (ANW), Atlas Air Worldwide (AAWW), Chico's FAS (CHS), Dollar Tree (DLTR), Garmin (GRMN), Par Pharmaceutical (PRX), Salesforce.com (CRM), Thomson Reuters (TRI) and Toll Brothers (TOL).
Data on new-home sales will also be out Wednesday.
Stocks Close Near Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks sold off Tuesday on a much worst-than-forecast drop in consumer confidence. The major indexes closed near their worst levels of the session.
The NYSE composite tumbled 1.5%, the Nasdaq 1.3%, the S&P 500 1.2% and the Dow 1.1%.
Volume climbed sharply across the board.
Alternative energy, steel and chips were among the worst groups. Foreign oil producers and household-related groups bucked the trend.
U.S. Stocks Cut More Losses; Chips Still Weak
BY VINCENT MAO
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks continued to pare losses in late trading Tuesday.
The Nasdaq lost 1.2%, up from a 1.6% deficit. But chip issues extended losses. The Philadelphia semiconductor index shed 3.2%. SanDisk (SNDK) dropped 5%, while Cree (CREE) fell 4%.
Elsewhere, the NYSE composite lost 1.3% and the S&P 500 1.1%. The Dow lost the least, containing its decline to 0.8%. Volume was tracking vastly higher on both exchanges.

TIM Participacoes (TSU) gapped down and dropped 6% in heavy trading. The Brazilian telecom service provider reports fourth-quarter earnings after the close. Views are for 26 cents a share, flat from a year ago.

Blue Coat Systems (BCSI) also reports after the close. The stock was off its intraday low but still down 1%. Analysts see the applications delivery firm's fiscal Q2 profit rising 62% to 26 cents a share. Revenue is slated to increase 14% to $124.5 million.
MercadoLibre (MELI) trimmed an earlier 10% loss to 7%. Late Monday, the Latin e-commerce firm reported Q4 results below views. It's been hurt by Venezuela's currency devaluation.
U.S. Stocks Crawl Off Low
BY VINCENT MAO
2:15 p.m. Update: Major indexes trimmed some losses in afternoon trading.

The Nasdaq pared an earlier 1.6% deficit to 1.4%. But chips continued to be a drag. The Philadelphia semiconductor index dropped 3.1%. SanDisk (SNDK) dropped 5% and breached its 50-day moving average.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite gave up 1.5% and the S&P 500 1.3%. The blue-chip Dow was down 1%. Turnover was tracking sharply higher on both exchanges.

Green Plains Renewable Energy (GPRE) erased earlier losses and climbed 5% to its best levels in more than two years. The ethanol producer followed through after clearing a cup base Monday. It has a Composite Rating of 99.
Pegasystems (PEGA) cut an earlier 11% loss to 1%. Earlier Tuesday, Roth Capital cut the software maker to hold from buy. It is thinly traded.
U.S. Stocks Extend Loss; Volume Picks Up
BY VINCENT MAO
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks stumbled to new session lows in early afternoon trading Tuesday.

The Nasdaq continued to lead the downside, falling 1.6%. Besides chips, many bellwethers traded lower. Apple (AAPL), Baidu (BIDU) and Google (GOOG) lost 2% each. The tech-heavy index also neared the 2200 level.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite dropped 1.5%, the S&P 500 1.3% and the Dow 1%.
Volume was again tracking higher across the board and has picked up.
Lam Research (LRCX) tumbled 7% and neared its 200-day moving average. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has fallen to a worst-possible E from A- last month.

Hittite Microwave (HITT) reversed early gains and dropped 4% in heavy trading. It's on pace to snap an eight-session win streak. The stock hit a near two-year high just two sessions ago. Last week, the integrated circuits maker reported flat Q4 earnings and a 6% drop in sales.
Cree (CREE) fell 3% in fast trade. It pulled back from a recent bounce off the 50-day line. The stock is on pace to end a nine-session advance.

On the plus side, Cracker Barrel (CBRL) gapped up and rallied 7% to a 19-month high. Before the open, the restaurant operator beat views with a 35% rise in fiscal Q2 earnings. Sales ticked up less than 1% to $632.6 million, missing views. The company pegged full-year earnings in range of $3.35 to $3.50 a share vs. views of $3.27 a share.
U.S. Stocks Ease Off Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks crawled off session lows after being decked by a much bigger-than-expected drop in consumer sentiment.

Hurt by losses in chip issues, the Nasdaq dropped 1.3% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The Philadelphia semiconductor index shed 3%. Meanwhile, the Dow also breached its 50-day line, falling 0.6%. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 lost 1.1% and 0.9%, respectively.
Volume was again tracking sharply higher on both exchanges.

IPC The Hospitalist (IPCM) gapped below its 50-day moving average and dived 12% in huge turnover. Late Monday, the firm guided 2010 sales between $352 million to $361 million vs. views of $374.8 million. The stock was down as much as 17%, but trimmed losses after hitting its 200-day moving average.
Sourcefire (FIRE) shed 5% in fast trade. The stock has met resistance at its 50-day moving average in recent sessions. But its Accumulation/Distribution has climbed to B- from D- late last month.
On the upside, China Automotive Systems (CAAS) turned a 4% loss into a 6% gain. The stock is building the right side of a new base. But it remains about 25% off a 52-week high.
Whole Foods Market (WFMI) reversed earlier losses and rose 2% in heavy trading. The stock hits its best levels in 21 months. Whole Foods cleared a cup base last Wednesday.
U.S. Stocks Turn Lower; Consumer Confidence Report Disappoints
BY JONAH KERI
11:15 a.m. Update: The major indexes fell sharply in late-morning action Tuesday, weighed down by a disappointing consumer confidence report.

The Dow fell 0.6%, the S&P 500 0.9%, the NYSE composite 1% and the Nasdaq 1.2%. Volume turned higher across the board. It rose 14% on the NYSE and 30% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Monday.

The Conference Board said its Consumer Confidence Index plunged almost 11 points to 46 in February. That was down from a revised reading of 56.5 in January. It also was well below the Street's estimate of 55.

Atheros Communications (ATHR) fell 3% in twice its normal trade. The maker of mixed-signal and digital semiconductor chip sets briefly touched a 52-week high on Monday before giving up most its intraday gains. It is No. 7 in the IBD 100.
ATP Oil & Gas (ATPG) dropped 5% in above-average turnover. The oil and gas natural gas exploration and production firm's stock sliced through its 50-day moving average. It has a 95 Composite Rating.

Amedisys (AMED) shed 2% in brisk volume, trimming earlier losses. The home nursing services provider reported quarterly earnings and revenue results above analysts' views. Amedisys' 2010 guidance also topped Wall Street forecasts.
U.S. Stocks Open Mixed; Housing Results Nip Estimates

5:15 p.m. Update:  Stocks fell on economic concerns Wednesday, but closed well off session lows. A couple of weak jobs reports and worse-than-expected services data trumped a surprise jump in factory orders.
The NYSE composite slipped just 0.2% after being down as much as 1.2%. Gains in banks, REITs and RV manufacturers helped to support the index. The Dow and S&P 500 fell 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively.
Meanwhile, the Nasdaq dropped 0.9%, up from a 1.5% deficit. But the index closed back under the 2000 level.
Volume spiked higher on the NYSE, giving the Dow and S&P 500 each a distribution day. The Nasdaq also logged a distribution day, as its turnover rose slightly.

Ctrip.com International (CTRP) gapped down and shed 8% in almost triple its average trade. The Chinese provider of online travel services gave a lackluster sales outlook late Tuesday. Wednesday morning, Susquehanna Financial downgraded shares to neutral from positive.
DynCorp International (DCP) gapped down and slumped 8% in nearly four times average trade. The company reported disappointing Q2 sales and announced a secondary stock offering.

On the upside, Lincoln Educational Services (LINC) gapped up and vaulted 11% to an all-time high. Before the open, the for-profit school operator delivered a 440% pop in Q2 earnings and raised its full-year outlook on profit and revenue.

Pegasystems (PEGA) reversed losses and ramped up nearly 9% to a 10-year peak. Late Tuesday, the business software maker smashed views with a 275% surge in Q2 profit. The stock is now 15% past a 24.59 buy point from a double-bottom base.
STEC (STEC) rose more than 2% in heavy trading. But the memory products maker was up over 7% at session peak.

Earnings Thursday: AECOM Technology (ACM), Air Methods (AIRM), Beazer Homes (BZH), Blackstone Group (BX), Brinker International (EAT), Continental Resources (CLR), Cubic (CUB), Fuqi International (FUQI), Inventiv Health (VTIV), Neutral Tandem (TNDM), Orion Marine (ORN) and SXC Health Solutions (SXCI).
Weekly jobless claims will be the only piece of economic data out Thursday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Late Rally Runs Out Of Gas
BY PATRICK CAIN
A late rebound faded a bit right before the close, leaving the major indexes in the red Wednesday.
The Dow fell 0.4%, the S&P 500 0.3%, the Nasdaq 0.9% and the NYSE composite 0.2%.
Decliners outpaced advancers by 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Volume was higher across the board. If confirmed, that would give all indexes but the NYSE a distribution day.
Despite market struggles, Lincoln Education (LINC) was able to blast up 12% after Tuesday night's bullish earnings report.
Recent hot stock United Travel Group (UTA), a Chinese travel agency, tried to rally back but ended down 6%. Shortly after the open, the firm fell 13%.
Grocer Whole Foods Markets (WFMI) shot up 16% after it posted earnings late Tuesday.
Banking-related industry groups were among the best, while auto and medicals were some of the weakest.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Work Off More Losses
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks pared more losses in late trading Wednesday, but were still on pace to finish lower for the first time in several sessions.
The Nasdaq dropped 1.1%. Cisco Systems (CSCO) slipped 1% ahead of its second-quarter results after the close. The networking giant is expected to earn 29 cents a share on sales of $8.52 billion.
Meanwhile, the Dow and S&P 500 each fell 0.4%. The NYSE composite lost 0.3%.
Financials rallied as Citigroup (C) jumped 8% on report that it's planning to sell several business units. Rivals Bank of America (BAC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) rose 6% and 4%, respectively.
Turnover was still tracking higher across the board.
Ninety-Nine Cents Only Stores (NDN) shaved most of an earlier 4% loss ahead of its earning report after the close. Analysts see the discount retailer's profit surging 89% to 17 cents a share.
ArcSight (ARST) erased earlier losses and climbed 3%. The security software maker recently regained its 50-day moving average, but has been trading mostly sideways since then.
2:15 p.m. Update: Recovery Efforts Accelerate In Afternoon Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks remained lower with two hours left in Wednesday's session, but they shaved more losses.
The Nasdaq was down 1.2%, the Dow 0.6%, the NYSE composite 0.5%. The S&P 500 was off 0.5%, but it crawled back above the 1000 level.
Volume continued to track higher on both exchanges, but at a much slower pace.
Tessera Technologies (TSRA) reversed from a 17-month high and fell 2%. Late Tuesday, the chip designer trounced views with a 131% surge in Q2 earnings and guided Q3 sales ahead of expectations.
Chip issues were under pressure along with the general market. The Philadelphia semiconductor index fell 1.6%, on pace to snap a four-session win streak.
Anaren (ANEN) tumbled 8% and sliced its 50-day moving average. It had been trading above the line for four months.
The communications equipment firm reports earnings Thursday after the close. Analysts see profit accelerating 108% to 27 cents a share.
Propane distributor Inergy (NRGY) fell 4% after Stifel Nicolaus cut shares to hold from buy.
On the upside, Pegasystems (PEGA) reversed earlier losses, rose 3% and hit a 10-year high in volatile trading.
1:15 p.m. Update: Nasdaq's Still Worse For Wear
BY VINCENT MAO
While most indexes trimmed losses, the Nasdaq remained near its session low in early afternoon trade.
The tech-heavy index dropped 1.4%. Bellwethers Apple (AAPL) and Google (GOOG) were lower. Cisco Systems (CSCO) also lost ground ahead of its Q2 results after the close.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite pared a 1.2% deficit to 0.7%. The S&P 500 also fell 0.7% and the Dow lost 0.8%.
Turnover was again tracking higher across the board, but the pace has slowed.

Ctrip.com International (CTRP) gapped down and shed 9% in heavy trading. Late Tuesday, the Chinese online travel firm delivered Q2 results above views, but gave a soft Q3 sales outlook. Earlier this morning, Susquehanna Financial cut shares to neutral from positive.

J2 Global Communications (JCOM) fell 4%, but appeared to have found support at its 50-day moving average. The provider of fax, e-mail and voice-mail services reports earnings after the close. Analysts are expecting a 10% rise in earnings and a 1% increase in sales.
12:15 a.m. Update: Nasdaq Leads Market's Decline
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
Stocks remained under pressure at midday Wednesday, with the Nasdaq on track for its worst decline in nearly a month.
The Nasdaq tumbled 1.2%. If that holds, it would be the composite's largest loss since a 2.3% tumble on July 7.
The S&P 500 was down 0.9% while the Dow and the NYSE composite were off 0.8% each.
Volume was tracking higher across the board.

Universal Travel Group (UTA) slid 0.87 to 15.96 in volume projected to exceed seven times its average. The China-based reservations and air cargo company remained 26% extended from a 12.70 buy point. The stock broke out July 28.

American Public Education (APEI) gapped down, losing 3.17 to 33.15 in huge turnover. The provider of higher education to military and government workers reported quarterly results late Tuesday. The company's Q3 earnings forecast was below analysts' consensus.
11:15 a.m. Update: Nasdaq, S&P 500 Lose Key Levels
BY VINCENT MAO
Major stock indexes piled on more losses in morning trade Wednesday.
The Nasdaq dropped 1%, falling back under the 2000 mark. Likewise, the S&P 500 lost 1% and slipped below the 1000 level. Meanwhile, the NYSE composite and the Dow fell 1.1% and 1%, respectively.
Turnover was again tracking sharply higher from Tuesday's pace.
Tekelec (TKLC) gapped down, dropped 8% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The telecom services firm delivered Q2 earnings above views, but its sales missed. At session low, the stock was down 14%.
DynCorp International (DCP) also gapped down and shed 8%. Late Tuesday, the provider of civilian and military services reported disappointing Q2 results and announced a secondary stock offering.
NetEase.com (NTES) lost 4% following a downgrade. Deutsche Securities cut the Chinese Internet portal to hold from buy.
Amazon.com (AMZN) regained a bit of ground after finding support at its 50-day line. But shares were down 2%. Sony (SNE) unveiled an e-book reader that's $100 lower than Amazon's Kindle.
On the upside, True Religion Apparel (TRLG) rallied 6% in wild trading. Earlier in the session, the stock cleared a 24.77 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Slump At Open
BY VINCENT MAO
Weak jobs and services data pressured stocks Wednesday following several days of gains.
On the economic front, June factory order rose 0.4% vs. estimates for a 0.8% decline.
The Nasdaq and NYSE composite each dropped 0.9% each, while the Dow and S&P 500 fell 0.8% apiece.
Volume was tracking sharply higher across the board.
The ISM services index slipped to 46.4 in July vs. expectations for an improvement to 48.
In company news, On2 Technologies (ONT) gapped up and gained 52% after Google (GOOG) agreed to buy the video compression firm for $106.5 million in stock.
Terra Industries (TRA) gapped up and rallied 6% after CF Industries (CF) said it's ready to sweeten its offer to buy Terra after two failed attempts.

On the downside, Ameristar Casinos (ASCA) gapped below its 50-day moving average and slumped 9% after it reported disappointing Q2 results. The stock had been trading in a double-bottom with handle, but never broke out.
Brink's Home Security (CFL) also delivered disappointing second-quarter earnings and sales. Shares fell 5%.
9:15 a.m. Update: Futures Slip After Employment Data
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures pointed to a slightly lower open Wednesday following disappointing jobs data.
Nasdaq 100 futures eased a fraction of a point vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures also lost a fraction of a point and Dow futures fell 20 points.
In economic news, the ADP employment report said the economy lost a bigger-than-expected 371,000 private-sector jobs in July. Still, that's down from a revised 463,000 in June.
Outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas said planned layoffs climbed 31% in July, the first increase in six months. That brought the total number of job cuts this year to 994,048.
The Labor Department's survey on private and public employment will be out Friday. Economists expect a loss of around 328,000 jobs.
Data on factory orders and the ISM services index will out at 10 a.m. EDT.

On the earnings front, Garmin (GRMN) surged 22% in pre-market trade after it smashed Q2 views despite a year-over-year decline. The GPS device maker's board approved a cash dividend of 75 cents a share.

Lumber Liquidators (LL) climbed 5% in pre-open trade after it delivered Q2 earnings and sales above views and gave a rosy outlook. The flooring retailer's profit and revenue grew 14% and 12%, respectively. It guided full-year earnings in as range of 85 cents to 91 cents a share vs. analysts' estimates of 84 cents. And it pegged 2009 sales in a range of $528 million to $538 million vs. expectations of $525.9 million.

Lincoln Education Services (LINC) reported Q2 results that easily beat views and raised its full-year outlook. The for-profit school operator's earnings surged more than five-fold to 27 cents a share. Sales gained 51% to $128.1 million. It guided full-year profit and revenue above views.
8:15 a.m. Update: Futures Down Ahead Of Economic Data
BY VANCE CARIAGA
Stock futures were down early Wednesday ahead of key reports on the labor market, factory orders and the services sector.
Futures for the S&P 500, Dow and Nasdaq all fell ahead of the opening bell.

On the economic front, the July ADP private-sector employment report is due before the markets open. Economists expect data to show that U.S. employers cut 345,000 private sector jobs for the month, down from the 473,000 shed in June.

The Institute for Supply Management is scheduled to release its July report on the services sector at 10 a.m. EDT. Economists see the ISM non-manufacturing index rising to 48.0 from 47.0 the previous month. A reading below 50 suggests the sector is contracting.
Also at 10 a.m., the Commerce Department releases June factory orders. Economists expect a monthly drop of 1% compared with a 1.2% increase in May.

In company news, Procter & Gamble (PG) said fiscal Q4 earnings fell 18% to 80 cents a share, though results still beat views by a penny. Revenue declined 11% to $18.7 billion, below estimates for $19.4 billion. The quarter ended A.G. Lafley's nine-year run as P&G's CEO. Bob McDonald took over July 1, while Lafley stays as chairman. Shares were down 1.7% in the pre-market.
Oil prices slipped 35 cents to $71.07 in electronic trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Overseas, Japan's Nikkei 225 closed down 1.2%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng slipped 1.5.

In Europe, the UK's FTSE 100 was up 0.2 in midday trading. Germany's DAX rose 0.1% and France's CAC-40 gained 0.6%.5:15 p.m. Update:  Stocks fell on economic concerns Wednesday, but closed well off session lows. A couple of weak jobs reports and worse-than-expected services data trumped a surprise jump in factory orders.The NYSE composite slipped just 0.2% after being down as much as 1.2%. Gains in banks, REITs and RV manufacturers helped to support the index. The Dow and S&P 500 fell 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively.Meanwhile, the Nasdaq dropped 0.9%, up from a 1.5% deficit. But the index closed back under the 2000 level.Volume spiked higher on the NYSE, giving the Dow and S&P 500 each a distribution day. The Nasdaq also logged a distribution day, as its turnover rose slightly.Ctrip.com International (CTRP) gapped down and shed 8% in almost triple its average trade. The Chinese provider of online travel services gave a lackluster sales outlook late Tuesday. Wednesday morning, Susquehanna Financial downgraded shares to neutral from positive.DynCorp International (DCP) gapped down and slumped 8% in nearly four times average trade. The company reported disappointing Q2 sales and announced a secondary stock offering.On the upside, Lincoln Educational Services (LINC) gapped up and vaulted 11% to an all-time high. Before the open, the for-profit school operator delivered a 440% pop in Q2 earnings and raised its full-year outlook on profit and revenue.Pegasystems (PEGA) reversed losses and ramped up nearly 9% to a 10-year peak. Late Tuesday, the business software maker smashed views with a 275% surge in Q2 profit. The stock is now 15% past a 24.59 buy point from a double-bottom base.STEC (STEC) rose more than 2% in heavy trading. But the memory products maker was up over 7% at session peak.Earnings Thursday: AECOM Technology (ACM), Air Methods (AIRM), Beazer Homes (BZH), Blackstone Group (BX), Brinker International (EAT), Continental Resources (CLR), Cubic (CUB), Fuqi International (FUQI), Inventiv Health (VTIV), Neutral Tandem (TNDM), Orion Marine (ORN) and SXC Health Solutions (SXCI).Weekly jobless claims will be the only piece of economic data out Thursday.4:15 p.m. Update: Late Rally Runs Out Of GasBY PATRICK CAINA late rebound faded a bit right before the close, leaving the major indexes in the red Wednesday.The Dow fell 0.4%, the S&P 500 0.3%, the Nasdaq 0.9% and the NYSE composite 0.2%.Decliners outpaced advancers by 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.Volume was higher across the board. If confirmed, that would give all indexes but the NYSE a distribution day.Despite market struggles, Lincoln Education (LINC) was able to blast up 12% after Tuesday night's bullish earnings report.Recent hot stock United Travel Group (UTA), a Chinese travel agency, tried to rally back but ended down 6%. Shortly after the open, the firm fell 13%.Grocer Whole Foods Markets (WFMI) shot up 16% after it posted earnings late Tuesday.Banking-related industry groups were among the best, while auto and medicals were some of the weakest.3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Work Off More LossesBY VINCENT MAOStocks pared more losses in late trading Wednesday, but were still on pace to finish lower for the first time in several sessions.The Nasdaq dropped 1.1%. Cisco Systems (CSCO) slipped 1% ahead of its second-quarter results after the close. The networking giant is expected to earn 29 cents a share on sales of $8.52 billion.Meanwhile, the Dow and S&P 500 each fell 0.4%. The NYSE composite lost 0.3%.Financials rallied as Citigroup (C) jumped 8% on report that it's planning to sell several business units. Rivals Bank of America (BAC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) rose 6% and 4%, respectively.Turnover was still tracking higher across the board.Ninety-Nine Cents Only Stores (NDN) shaved most of an earlier 4% loss ahead of its earning report after the close. Analysts see the discount retailer's profit surging 89% to 17 cents a share.ArcSight (ARST) erased earlier losses and climbed 3%. The security software maker recently regained its 50-day moving average, but has been trading mostly sideways since then.2:15 p.m. Update: Recovery Efforts Accelerate In Afternoon TradeBY VINCENT MAOStocks remained lower with two hours left in Wednesday's session, but they shaved more losses.The Nasdaq was down 1.2%, the Dow 0.6%, the NYSE composite 0.5%. The S&P 500 was off 0.5%, but it crawled back above the 1000 level.Volume continued to track higher on both exchanges, but at a much slower pace.Tessera Technologies (TSRA) reversed from a 17-month high and fell 2%. Late Tuesday, the chip designer trounced views with a 131% surge in Q2 earnings and guided Q3 sales ahead of expectations.Chip issues were under pressure along with the general market. The Philadelphia semiconductor index fell 1.6%, on pace to snap a four-session win streak.Anaren (ANEN) tumbled 8% and sliced its 50-day moving average. It had been trading above the line for four months.The communications equipment firm reports earnings Thursday after the close. Analysts see profit accelerating 108% to 27 cents a share.Propane distributor Inergy (NRGY) fell 4% after Stifel Nicolaus cut shares to hold from buy.On the upside, Pegasystems (PEGA) reversed earlier losses, rose 3% and hit a 10-year high in volatile trading.1:15 p.m. Update: Nasdaq's Still Worse For WearBY VINCENT MAOWhile most indexes trimmed losses, the Nasdaq remained near its session low in early afternoon trade.The tech-heavy index dropped 1.4%. Bellwethers Apple (AAPL) and Google (GOOG) were lower. Cisco Systems (CSCO) also lost ground ahead of its Q2 results after the close.Meanwhile, the NYSE composite pared a 1.2% deficit to 0.7%. The S&P 500 also fell 0.7% and the Dow lost 0.8%.Turnover was again tracking higher across the board, but the pace has slowed.Ctrip.com International (CTRP) gapped down and shed 9% in heavy trading. Late Tuesday, the Chinese online travel firm delivered Q2 results above views, but gave a soft Q3 sales outlook. Earlier this morning, Susquehanna Financial cut shares to neutral from positive.J2 Global Communications (JCOM) fell 4%, but appeared to have found support at its 50-day moving average. The provider of fax, e-mail and voice-mail services reports earnings after the close. Analysts are expecting a 10% rise in earnings and a 1% increase in sales.12:15 a.m. Update: Nasdaq Leads Market's DeclineBY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIAStocks remained under pressure at midday Wednesday, with the Nasdaq on track for its worst decline in nearly a month.The Nasdaq tumbled 1.2%. If that holds, it would be the composite's largest loss since a 2.3% tumble on July 7.The S&P 500 was down 0.9% while the Dow and the NYSE composite were off 0.8% each.Volume was tracking higher across the board.Universal Travel Group (UTA) slid 0.87 to 15.96 in volume projected to exceed seven times its average. The China-based reservations and air cargo company remained 26% extended from a 12.70 buy point. The stock broke out July 28.American Public Education (APEI) gapped down, losing 3.17 to 33.15 in huge turnover. The provider of higher education to military and government workers reported quarterly results late Tuesday. The company's Q3 earnings forecast was below analysts' consensus.11:15 a.m. Update: Nasdaq, S&P 500 Lose Key LevelsBY VINCENT MAOMajor stock indexes piled on more losses in morning trade Wednesday.The Nasdaq dropped 1%, falling back under the 2000 mark. Likewise, the S&P 500 lost 1% and slipped below the 1000 level. Meanwhile, the NYSE composite and the Dow fell 1.1% and 1%, respectively.Turnover was again tracking sharply higher from Tuesday's pace.Tekelec (TKLC) gapped down, dropped 8% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The telecom services firm delivered Q2 earnings above views, but its sales missed. At session low, the stock was down 14%.DynCorp International (DCP) also gapped down and shed 8%. Late Tuesday, the provider of civilian and military services reported disappointing Q2 results and announced a secondary stock offering.NetEase.com (NTES) lost 4% following a downgrade. Deutsche Securities cut the Chinese Internet portal to hold from buy.Amazon.com (AMZN) regained a bit of ground after finding support at its 50-day line. But shares were down 2%. Sony (SNE) unveiled an e-book reader that's $100 lower than Amazon's Kindle.On the upside, True Religion Apparel (TRLG) rallied 6% in wild trading. Earlier in the session, the stock cleared a 24.77 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Slump At OpenBY VINCENT MAOWeak jobs and services data pressured stocks Wednesday following several days of gains.On the economic front, June factory order rose 0.4% vs. estimates for a 0.8% decline.The Nasdaq and NYSE composite each dropped 0.9% each, while the Dow and S&P 500 fell 0.8% apiece.Volume was tracking sharply higher across the board.The ISM services index slipped to 46.4 in July vs. expectations for an improvement to 48.In company news, On2 Technologies (ONT) gapped up and gained 52% after Google (GOOG) agreed to buy the video compression firm for $106.5 million in stock.Terra Industries (TRA) gapped up and rallied 6% after CF Industries (CF) said it's ready to sweeten its offer to buy Terra after two failed attempts.On the downside, Ameristar Casinos (ASCA) gapped below its 50-day moving average and slumped 9% after it reported disappointing Q2 results. The stock had been trading in a double-bottom with handle, but never broke out.Brink's Home Security (CFL) also delivered disappointing second-quarter earnings and sales. Shares fell 5%.9:15 a.m. Update: Futures Slip After Employment DataBY VINCENT MAOStock futures pointed to a slightly lower open Wednesday following disappointing jobs data.Nasdaq 100 futures eased a fraction of a point vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures also lost a fraction of a point and Dow futures fell 20 points.In economic news, the ADP employment report said the economy lost a bigger-than-expected 371,000 private-sector jobs in July. Still, that's down from a revised 463,000 in June.Outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas said planned layoffs climbed 31% in July, the first increase in six months. That brought the total number of job cuts this year to 994,048.The Labor Department's survey on private and public employment will be out Friday. Economists expect a loss of around 328,000 jobs.Data on factory orders and the ISM services index will out at 10 a.m. EDT.On the earnings front, Garmin (GRMN) surged 22% in pre-market trade after it smashed Q2 views despite a year-over-year decline. The GPS device maker's board approved a cash dividend of 75 cents a share.Lumber Liquidators (LL) climbed 5% in pre-open trade after it delivered Q2 earnings and sales above views and gave a rosy outlook. The flooring retailer's profit and revenue grew 14% and 12%, respectively. It guided full-year earnings in as range of 85 cents to 91 cents a share vs. analysts' estimates of 84 cents. And it pegged 2009 sales in a range of $528 million to $538 million vs. expectations of $525.9 million.Lincoln Education Services (LINC) reported Q2 results that easily beat views and raised its full-year outlook. The for-profit school operator's earnings surged more than five-fold to 27 cents a share. Sales gained 51% to $128.1 million. It guided full-year profit and revenue above views.8:15 a.m. Update: Futures Down Ahead Of Economic DataBY VANCE CARIAGAStock futures were down early Wednesday ahead of key reports on the labor market, factory orders and the services sector.Futures for the S&P 500, Dow and Nasdaq all fell ahead of the opening bell.On the economic front, the July ADP private-sector employment report is due before the markets open. Economists expect data to show that U.S. employers cut 345,000 private sector jobs for the month, down from the 473,000 shed in June.The Institute for Supply Management is scheduled to release its July report on the services sector at 10 a.m. EDT. Economists see the ISM non-manufacturing index rising to 48.0 from 47.0 the previous month. A reading below 50 suggests the sector is contracting.Also at 10 a.m., the Commerce Department releases June factory orders. Economists expect a monthly drop of 1% compared with a 1.2% increase in May.In company news, Procter & Gamble (PG) said fiscal Q4 earnings fell 18% to 80 cents a share, though results still beat views by a penny. Revenue declined 11% to $18.7 billion, below estimates for $19.4 billion. The quarter ended A.G. Lafley's nine-year run as P&G's CEO. Bob McDonald took over July 1, while Lafley stays as chairman. Shares were down 1.7% in the pre-market.Oil prices slipped 35 cents to $71.07 in electronic trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.Overseas, Japan's Nikkei 225 closed down 1.2%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng slipped 1.5.In Europe, the UK's FTSE 100 was up 0.2 in midday trading. Germany's DAX rose 0.1% and France's CAC-40 gained 0.6%.
Concerns over the European debt crisis slammed stocks Tuesday, overshadowing better-than-expected factory and housing data.
The Nasdaq dumped 3%, its biggest loss in three months. Chips and high-profile issues weighed on the tech-heavy index. The Philadelphia semiconductor index tumbled nearly 5%.
Amazon.com (AMZN) dropped nearly 6%. Google (GOOG) fell 5%, while Apple (AAPL) and Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) lost 3% each.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite dropped 2.7%, breaching its 50-day moving average. Volume surged across the board.
The dollar also surged, driving the euro down to a one-year low. Oil fell 4%. Gold lost about 1%.
Leaders got whacked, too. In the IBD 100, 91 stocks closed lower.

DineEquity (DIN) gapped down and tumbled 13% in more than double its average volume. The stock sliced its 50-day moving average. Earlier Tuesday, the operator and franchiser of Applebee's and IHOP restaurants smashed views with a 50% jump in Q1 earnings. Sales fell 5% to $358 million, but that was below views.
Steven Madden (SHOO) shed nearly 8% in more than double its average trade. The shoe designer gave a disappointing full-year EPS outlook.
Aixtron (AIXG) gapped down and shed 7% in heavy trading. The stock closed slightly above its 200-day moving average.
After the close, Intermune (ITNM) plunged 80% after the Food and Drug Administration rejected its perfinedone lung treatment.
True Religion Apparel (TRLG) fell 5%, despite reporting Q1 results above views.
Earnings Wednesday: Alpha Natural Resources (ANR), Career Education (CECO), Garmin (GRMN), Lincoln Educational Resources (LINC), Medifast (MED) and TRW Automotive. (TRW)
The ADP employment survey and the ISM services index will also be out Wednesday.
U.S. Stocks Down Sharply, But End off Session Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
Overseas debt worries hurt stocks Tuesday, but the major averages finished off their worst levels of the session, thanks to a late rally.

The Nasdaq dropped 3% after falling as much as 3.5% intraday. The NYSE composite fell 2.7%, S&P 500 2.4% and Dow 2%. Volume surged across the board. Decliners trounced advancers by about 6-to-1 on the NYSE and more than 5-to-1 on the Nasdaq.

Nearly all 197 industry groups tracked by IBD lost ground. Internet service providers and concrete producers were among the worst performers. Economically sensitive groups such as machinery, metals and steel also faltered.
Comeback Fades In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Rebound efforts faded in late trading Tuesday, sending stocks back near their worst levels of the session.

The Nasdaq lost 3.2%. Chip stocks continued to get whacked. The Philadelphia semiconductor index dropped 5.1%. Bellwether issues also tumbled. Amazon.com (AMZN) dropped 6%. Google (GOOG) lost 4%, and Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) fell 3%.
Volume was again tracking vastly higher on both exchanges. Three of the four indexes remained above their 50-day moving average. However, the NYSE composite fell underneath the key area.

True Religion Apparel (TRLG) fell 5% on a downgrade. Citing valuation, Lazard Capital Markets cut the high-priced jeans maker to hold from buy. True Religion reports quarterly results after the close. Analysts are expecting 33 cents a share on sales of $73.4 million.
WebMD Health (WBMD) and OpenTable (OPEN) will also unveil earnings after the close. They fell 3% and 2%, respectively.

On the upside, Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) rose 3% to a near- record high. On Monday, the drugmaker beat views with a 39% rise in Q1 earnings and a 30% gain in sales. It also announced an acquisition.
U.S. Stocks Crawl Off Session Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
The major indexes eased off session lows in afternoon trading Tuesday.
The Nasdaq trimmed an earlier 3.5% shortfall to 3.1%. The NYSE composite was down 2.6%, the S&P 500 2.2% and the Dow 2%. Volume was tracking sharply higher across the board.
Bonds rallied, sending the yield on the 10-year note to 3.62% from 3.70% late Monday. Gold fell from a five-month high. The June contract settled at $1,169.80 an ounce, down $13.50.
Losses in chip stocks weighed on the Nasdaq.
Aixtron (AIXG) gapped down, shedding 7% as it neared its 200-day moving average. The stock has been trading above its 200-day line for more than a year.
Atheros Communications (ATHR) dropped 7% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has weakened to D+ from B+ two weeks ago.
Cree (CREE) fell 5% and breached its 50-day line.
The Philadelphia semiconductor index dived more than 5% to a one-month low.
Elsewhere, Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) lost 5%, breaching its 50-day line. The stock fell 5% below a 30.33 buy point from a base-on-base pattern.
On the upside, Herbalife (HLF) pulled back from a new record high, but was still up 2%. Late Monday, the dietary supplements maker beat views with a 44% jump in Q1 earnings.
U.S. Stocks Near Lows; NYSE Composite Loses 50-Day Line
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks remained deep in the red, near session lows in early afternoon trading Tuesday.

The NYSE composite shed 2.8% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The Nasdaq stumbled 3.2% and the S&P 500 2.4%, as both neared their 50-day lines. The Dow lost 2.2%, with 27 of 30 components on the downside.
Volume continued to track vastly higher on both exchanges.

DineEquity (DIN) gapped down, diving 10% and slicing its 50-day moving average. Earlier Tuesday, the operator of Applebees and IHOP restaurants smashed views with a 50% jump in Q1 earnings. Sales fell 5% to $358 million, below views.
Group mate Domino's Pizza (DPZ) gapped down and swooned 11% despite delivering Q1 results above analysts' estimates. The stock trimmed some losses after finding support near its 50-day line.
Elsewhere, Blue Coat Systems (BCSI) dropped 6% and breached its 50-day moving average. The sell-off puts the stock nearly 7% below a 33.76 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Ann Taylor Stores (ANN) gapped up and bolted 9% to a 20-month high. Before the open, the women's apparel retailer said it expects Q1 sales of $475 million vs. views for $455.6 million. It also expects earnings to "significantly exceed expectations." Ann Taylor reports May 21.
Nasdaq Leads U.S. Stocks' Big Losses At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes sustained heavy losses at midday Tuesday, as big-cap techs' decline paced a broad-based morning sell-off.
The Nasdaq plunged 2.9%, leading the way down. The index is on pace for its biggest percentage loss of the year. The NYSE composite fell 2.6%, the S&P 500 2.2% and the Dow 1.9%.
Volume swelled across the board. It rose 42% on the NYSE and 45% on the Nasdaq, compared with the same period Monday. Top-rated stocks felt the sting of the broad market's decline.

AsiaInfo Holdings (ASIA) sank 5% in five times its normal trade. The Chinese software and IT security firm sliced through its 50-day moving average following an uninspiring first-quarter earnings report.
NetApp (NTAP) gave up 4% in brisk volume. The maker of network storage and data management hardware also pierced its 50-day moving average.

Apple (AAPL) fell 3% in nearly double its typical turnover. The iPod, iPhone and iPad maker remains in a strong uptrend and owns a highest-possible 99 IBD Earnings Per Share Rating. It remains well above its 50-day line.
U.S. Stocks Dive As Greece Woes Overshadow Economic Reports

5:15 p.m. Update: A surprising drop in consumer sentiment sent stocks reeling across the board Friday, but a late rally shaved a chunk of losses.
The Nasdaq lost 1.2%, closing back under the 2000 level. The S&P 500 fell 0.9%, but finished above the 1000 mark.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite and Dow dropped 1% and 0.8%, respectively.
Volume fell on the Nasdaq. But NYSE turnover surged partly due to heightened trading in Citigroup (C). Thursday's NYSE volume may have been artificially low because of electronic trading problems.
All four major indexes snapped their four-week win streaks. The Nasdaq and NYSE composite each fell 0.7%, while the S&P 500 lost 0.6% and Dow 0.5%.

Jinpan International (JST) gapped down, dived 20% and sliced its 50-day moving average. Before the open, the electrical equipment maker smashed views with a 45% jump in Q2 earnings. But the company guided full-year sales below analysts' estimates.

Coinstar (CSTR) tumbled 10% on over five-times average trade. Redbox, a unit of Coinstar, is suing 20th Century Fox for trying to block it from renting films as they become available for release. This hampers DVD sales.

Neutral Tandem (TNDM) dropped 6% in nearly twice its average trade. The telecom services provider has lost more than 18% in the last two weeks. Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating has weakened to D-.

On the upside, VanceInfo Technologies (VIT) gapped up and rallied 7% in over doubled its average trade. Before the open, the Chinese IT firm smashed views with a 40% rise in Q2 earnings and raised its full-year outlook.
Agilent Technologies (A), Lowe's (LOW) and Trina Solar (TSL) are among a handful of companies reporting earnings on Monday.
The Empire State Manufacturing Survey will also be out Monday.
4:15 p.m. Update: Indexes End Off Session Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks tumbled Friday, but a late-session rally trimmed losses some.
The Nasdaq dropped 1.2%, but that's up from a 2% loss. The NYSE composite fell 1%, S&P 500 0.9% and Dow 0.8%.
Volume climbed sharply on the NYSE and fell on the Nasdaq. Decliners beat advancers 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq and more than 3-to-1 on the NYSE.
Metal products distributors, automakers and pollution control firms were some of the session's worst performers. Some banks bucked the sell-off.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks On Pace For First Down Week In Five
BY VINCENT MAOStocks were again near session lows late Friday and on pace to finish lower for the first time in five weeks.
The Nasdaq was down 1.8%, up from a 2% deficit. The NYSE composite lost 1.6%, while the Dow and S&P 500 shed 1.4% each.
Turnover was again mixed: lower on the Nasdaq and sharply higher on the NYSE.
Coinstar (CSTR) tumbled 10% in huge volume. Late Thursday, the company's Redbox movie rental unit sued 20th Century Fox over the timing of new-release titles.
Carter's (CRI) fell 4% in heavy trade and slipped below a 24.56 buy point from a cup base. But the stock appeared to have found support at its 50-day moving average.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) dipped 4%. The restaurant operator fell further below an 89.65 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Potential support from the stock's 50-day moving average lies just below.
2:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Near Lows In Mixed Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks hovered near session lows with a couple of hours left in Friday's session.
The Nasdaq dropped back under the 2000 level, falling 1.9%. The S&P 500 fell below the 1000 mark, down 1.6%.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite lost 1.7% and Dow 1.5%.

Nasdaq trade was tracking lower. But NYSE volume was tracking sharply higher, partly due to increased trading in Citigroup (C). Shares edged lower despite getting an upgrade from Bank of America. Citigroup has almost traded twice its average daily volume.
Neutral Tandem (TNDM) tumbled 8% to a two-month low. The telecom services provider is now 28% off its Aug. 3 high.

CNinsure (CISG) dropped 5% in heavy trading, giving back a good chunk of Thursday's move. The Chinese insurance firm reports Q2 results Aug. 26. Analysts are expecting flat earnings of 19 cents a share.

Garmin (GRMN) gapped down and shed 5% after Goldman Sachs added the GPS device maker to its Americas Conviction Sell List. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has weakened to C+ from A seven sessions ago.
1:15 p.m. Update: Market Holds Lower
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks traded lower in mixed volume in early-afternoon action Friday.
The Dow sank 1.4%, the S&P 500 1.5%, the Nasdaq 1.8% and the NYSE composite 1.5%.
Volume was running much higher on the NYSE, which had an unusually light day Thursday, and slightly lower on the Nasdaq. Declining stocks continued to lead advancers by a wide margin.
China Green Agriculture (CGA) dropped 6% in more than twice its normal trade. The fertilizer maker has surged since breaking out of a nine-week consolidation on July 24.
Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) fell 2% in brisk volume. The maker of personal care products has traded in a narrow range in the past two weeks and sits 5% off its 52-week high.
On the upside, Universal Travel (UTA) rose 3% in rapid turnover. The Chinese travel services provider's stock staged a big negative reversal Thursday after posting Q2 earnings results.
12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Retain Losses At Midday

5:15 p.m. Update: A surprising drop in consumer sentiment sent stocks reeling across the board Friday, but a late rally shaved a chunk of losses.The Nasdaq lost 1.2%, closing back under the 2000 level. The S&P 500 fell 0.9%, but finished above the 1000 mark.Meanwhile, the NYSE composite and Dow dropped 1% and 0.8%, respectively.Volume fell on the Nasdaq. But NYSE turnover surged partly due to heightened trading in Citigroup (C). Thursday's NYSE volume may have been artificially low because of electronic trading problems.All four major indexes snapped their four-week win streaks. The Nasdaq and NYSE composite each fell 0.7%, while the S&P 500 lost 0.6% and Dow 0.5%.Jinpan International (JST) gapped down, dived 20% and sliced its 50-day moving average. Before the open, the electrical equipment maker smashed views with a 45% jump in Q2 earnings. But the company guided full-year sales below analysts' estimates.Coinstar (CSTR) tumbled 10% on over five-times average trade. Redbox, a unit of Coinstar, is suing 20th Century Fox for trying to block it from renting films as they become available for release. This hampers DVD sales.Neutral Tandem (TNDM) dropped 6% in nearly twice its average trade. The telecom services provider has lost more than 18% in the last two weeks. Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating has weakened to D-.On the upside, VanceInfo Technologies (VIT) gapped up and rallied 7% in over doubled its average trade. The Chinese travel services provider's stock staged a big negative reversal Thursday after posting Q2 earnings results.12:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Retain Losses At Midday
After closing in a tailspin, the market was disappointed with results of two notable big caps after hours.

Business software giant Oracle (ORCL) said its Q3 earnings rose 9% to 38 cents a share, matching estimates. Sales grew 16% to $6.4 billion. If not for the integration of Sun, quarterly sales would have jumped only 7%. Oracle acquired Sun in January for $7.4 billion.
"The Sun integration is going even better than we expected," Oracle President Safra Catz said in a prepared statement.
Shares were down 1% in after-hours trading.

Accenture (ACN) fell 2% after the company said Q3 earnings slipped to 60 cents a share, missing views for flat earnings. Revenue fell 2% to $5.18 billion in U.S. dollar terms. The Irish company's revenue fell 8% in the local currency.
No notable stocks report before the close Friday, but there will be economic data to watch.
Before the bell, final Q4 GDP figures are expected to be released. The Street expects 0.4% growth. Shortly after the open, consumer sentiment data will be announced.
Weak Ending Wipes Out Gains For U.S. Stocks
BY PATRICK CAIN
Stocks ended mostly lower Thursday, as weakness persisted throughout the afternoon.

The Dow closed fractionally higher. The Nasdaq fell 0.1% and the S&P 500 lost 0.2%. The NYSE composite shed 0.3%. Volume was higher across the board, according to preliminary data. At the day's high, the Dow was up 1.4% and other indexes were up at least 0.9%.
A handful of strong earnings put investors in a buying mood early, but the rally faded.
A Treasury bond auction showed weak demand, pushing the buck higher.

Still, a few stocks broke out, including China Automotive Systems (CAAS), which passed its buy point of 24 from a sloppy, deep cup-with-handle base. The maker of power steering systems topped earnings expectations.
Amazon (AMZN) also passed a buy point. The Internet retail giant gained 7%, passing its 134.30 cup-with-handle buy point.

The Internet retail giant gained 7%, passing its 134.30 cup-with-handle buy point.U.S. Stocks Ease Further From Highs; Natural Gas Producers Take Hit

Stocks were mostly higher in early afternoon trading Wednesday. The broad market recouped some of the prior session's heavy losses, but blue chips struggled for direction.The Nasdaq was up 0.5%, the NYSE composite 0.4% and the S&P 500 0.2%. Meanwhile, the Dow was unchanged as winners and losers in the 30-stock index were virtually even. Turnover was again tracking sharply lower across the board.Kronos Worldwide (KRO) gapped up and leapt nearly 9% in active trading. On Tuesday, the stock reversed higher after finding support near its 50-day moving average. Kronos makes titanium dioxide pigments used in coatings, plastics and cosmetics. The company lost money in the past two years, but it's slated to turn a profit of $2.54 a share this year and $3.21 a share in 2011.Coach (COH) climbed 4% in fast trade. The stock retraced Tuesday's losses and came close to its Nov. 9 peak. Last month, the high-end handbag retailer beat views with a 43% rise in fiscal Q1 earnings.Other luxury goods retailers, including Nordstrom (JWN) and Saks Fifth Avenue (SKS), have recently delivered upbeat quarterly earnings. They rose 2% each.On the downside, solar stocks took heat after Credit Suisse downgraded the sector to market weight and said demand couldn't keep up with growing supply. Credit Suisse cut Trina Solar (TSL) to neutral from outperform. The stock gapped below its 200-day moving average and fell 4%. First Solar (FSLR) fell 5% after receiving the same downgrade.Amtech Systems (ASYS) tumbled 10% and sliced its 50-day moving average. The company produces equipment used in making solar cells and semiconductor devices.
5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks again wrestled with the dollar Wednesday. Only this time, equities came out on top after the greenback sold off late in the session.

The Dow and Nasdaq gained 0.5% each. The Nasdaq 100 rallied 1%, thanks to high-profile tech issues. Apple (AAPL) rose 4% and regained its 50-day moving average. According to analyst reports, the tech icon is on track to launch a tablet computer early next year. Research In Motion (RIMM) and Garmin (GRMN) gained 5% and 4%, respectively.
Meanwhile, the S&P 500 rose 0.4%, and the NYSE composite edged up 0.2%. The latter index again closed above its 50-day moving average after breaching the line intraday.
Turnover fell on both exchanges.

Hi-Tech Pharmacal (HITK) gapped up and surged 12% in four times average volume. Before the open, the drugmaker delivered fiscal Q2 results well above views. Hi-Tech is in a cup base with a 25.70 buy point. Schweitzer-Mauduit International (SWM) rallied 8% to a record high in heavy volume. The paper products maker cleared a short consolidation.
Fellow paper firm Clearwater Paper (CLW) erased morning losses and rose 2% in active trading. It followed through from Tuesday's breakout. But the stock didn't hit a new high.
On the downside, Men's Wearhouse (MW) gapped down and dropped 7% in big volume. The suit retailer gave a weak Q4 outlook.
Jos. A. Bank Clothiers (JOSB), which also sells suits, lost 3% in more than twice its average trade.
Citigroup (C) reversed lower and lost 2%. According to CNBC, the bank is talking to regulators about returning the $45 billion it borrowed from the Troubled Asset Relief Program.

Bank of America (BAC) slipped a fraction. It repaid the $45 billion it borrowed from the government's bailout program. Last week, BofA raised $19.3 billion in a stock offering to help with the repayment.
In after-hours news, Lululemon Athletica (LULU) reported Q3 earnings and sales above views. Shares rose 1% after hours.
Earnings Thursday: Ciena (CIEN), Costco (COST), Dollar General (DG), Esterline Technologies (ESL), Gildan Activewear (GIL) and National Semiconductor (NSM).
Jobless claims, trade balance and the Treasury budget will also be out Thursday.
Stocks Close At Session Highs
BY VINCENT MAO
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks finished at session highs Wednesday, thanks to a late-day rally.
The Dow and Nasdaq gained 0.5% each, while the S&P 500 rose 0.4%. The NYSE composite edged up 0.2%. According to preliminary data, volume fell on both exchanges.
Computer makers, gold and steel were the session's best sectors. Homebuilders, hospital operators and retail groups were among the worst performers.
Indexes Improve In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks improved after the dollar pulled back in late trading Wednesday.

The Dow edged up 0.1%, while the S&P 500 turned flat. The tech-heavy Nasdaq, down 0.8% at its session low, also was at break-even. The big-cap Nasdaq 100 rose 0.4%, led by Apple (AAPL) and Research In Motion (RIMM). The NYSE composite, weighed down by energy stocks, fell 0.2%.
Volume was again tracking lower on both exchanges.
Hi-Tech Pharmacal (HITK) held onto an 11% gain after gapping higher this morning. Before the open, the drugmaker smashed views with a 567% pop in fiscal Q2 profit. It also trounced views on revenue.

American Superconductor (AMSC) reversed earlier losses and gained 5%. The stock is near a 37.58 buy point from a three-month base. American Superconductor makes wind turbines and electrical control systems.

Lululemon Athletica (LULU) reversed morning losses and climbed 3% in active trading. The yoga apparel and accessories retailer reports earnings after the close. Analysts are expecting profit of 19 cents a share on sales of $111.2 million. Lululemon is trading in a cup-with-handle pattern.
Stocks Worsen In Afternoon Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks further weakened in afternoon trading Wednesday, as the dollar continued to rebound. Even the Dow turned lower after treading water.
The NYSE composite shed 0.7%, breaching its 50-day moving average. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 lost 0.4% each. Meanwhile, the Dow fell 0.2%. Twenty of 30 components traded on the downside.
Turnover continued to track lower across the board.

MercadoLibre (MELI) lost 3% in fast trade. It erased Tuesday's move and then some. The stock has given back nearly all gains after clearing a 47.85 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern last month.

Ebix (EBIX) reversed morning gains and lost 5% in heavy trading. The stock has been vacillating below its 50-day moving average for about a month. Despite the sideways movement, its Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to C+ from D-.
Energy issues were under pressure after oil fell below $71 a barrel.
Atwood Oceanics (ATW) fell 2% to a two-month low in active trading. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating fell to D- from B- six sessions ago.
Indexes Weaken In Early Afternoon Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks weakened and continued to trade in split fashion in early afternoon trading Wednesday.
Thanks to a jump in 3M (MMM), the Dow rose 0.1%. Citigroup upgraded the conglomerate to buy from hold. Meanwhile, the NYSE composite fell 0.5%, the Nasdaq 0.3% and the S&P 500 0.2%.
Volume was again trading lower across the board.

Steven Madden (SHOO) rallied 5% and regained its 50-day moving average. The stock is forming a new base. Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating improved to B from D- in early November. Steven Madden's earnings growth accelerated in the past two quarters.

Tri-Tech Holding (TRIT) erased earlier losses and vaulted 6% to a record high. The Chinese company makes systems that monitor and manage natural and municipal water resources. Its earnings have doubled for two straight quarters. Sales grew by triple digits for three of the past four periods.

Despite another drop in gold, Silver Wheaton (SLW) rose 3% in fast trade. Last month, the silver and gold producer reported a 38% rise in Q3 earnings and snapped three straight period of declines. Analysts see profit surging 250% in the current period.
On the downside, Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) reversed morning gains and fell 2% in fast trade. The stock was up 2% at session peak.
Stocks Narrowly Mixed At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
12:15 p.m. Update: The major indexes turned narrowly mixed at midday Wednesday. The Dow rose 0.2%. On the downside, the NYSE composite fell 0.2%, the Nasdaq 0.1%. The S&P 500 was trading flat.

Volume turned lower across the board. It fell 13% on the NYSE and 4% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Tuesday. Advancing issues had an edge over decliners on the NYSE, but trailed on the Nasdaq.
Wholesale inventories rose 0.3% in October, beating economists' expectations of a 0.5% decline. Inventories dropped 0.8% in September.

Sales at the wholesale level advanced 1.2% in October, topping views of 0.7% growth. That followed a 1.3% rise in September and marked the seventh straight month that sales at the wholesale level picked up.

Rue21 (RUE) surged 7% in more than twice its normal trade. The youth-oriented apparel chain operator vaulted to an all-time high on a bullish third-quarter earnings report. The stock went public on Nov. 13.

Apple (AAPL) rose 2% in nearly double its usual turnover. The iPod and iPhone maker is trying to bounce back to its 50-day moving average after piercing that line last week. An Oppenheimer analyst said Apple is ramping up development of its new tablet product.
Gulfport Energy (GPOR) leapt 11% in more than triple its average volume. The oil and gas exploration and production company hit a 52-week high.
Market Turns Higher
